question:
I am a 55-year-old postmenopausal woman who has been experiencing sharp pain in my right groin for the past two weeks. I have noticed that the pain is alleviated when I stand. During a recent check-up, my blood pressure was measured at 140/92 mm Hg, and my heart rate was 88 beats per minute. The examination of my heart revealed no murmurs or gallops.

When evaluated further, my abdominal, lung, and genitourinary examinations did not show any significant findings, and there were no palpable hernias. An osteopathic evaluation indicated tenderness in the right paraspinal region at the L4 and L5 vertebrae. Additionally, I had a shallow right sacral sulcus and a posterior right inferior lateral angle. The seated flexion test was positive on the right side.

Radiographic imaging of my hip and lumbar spine did not reveal any acute or chronic abnormalities. Based on these findings, I am trying to understand which structure might be implicated in my condition, considering options such as the sacrotuberous ligament, quadratus lumborum muscle, piriformis muscle, and several others.
options: A. Sacrotuberous ligament B. Quadratus lumborum muscle C. Piriformis muscle D. Posterior sacroiliac ligament E. Iliolumbar ligament F. Anterior sacroiliac ligament G. Psoas major muscle H. Sacrospinous ligament I. Gluteus medius muscle J. Iliacus muscle
default: Based on your symptoms and the findings from the osteopathic evaluation, the structure most likely implicated in your condition is the **piriformis muscle**. The tenderness in the right paraspinal region and the positive seated flexion test suggest potential involvement of the sacroiliac joint and surrounding musculature, including the piriformis. This muscle can refer pain to the groin area, especially if it is tight or in spasm. Additionally, the alleviation of pain when standing may indicate a positional component related to the pelvis and hip mechanics.

question:
Shortly after my birth, I began to experience tachypnea and retractions, with a respiratory rate of 90 breaths per minute. Despite these symptoms, I did not show any signs of cyanosis and appeared active without looking ill. My delivery took place via cesarean section at 38 weeks, following an uneventful pregnancy, and I was subsequently placed under observation in intensive care.

During my time in the unit, blood gas analysis indicated that I was not retaining CO2, and there were no other concerning findings such as fever or rash. The medical team assessed my condition and considered several management options. They weighed the possibility that my symptoms could be benign and self-limiting versus potential concerns like pneumonia or sepsis.

Ultimately, the medical team determined that my condition was likely transient tachypnea of the newborn and did not require any specific treatment or antibiotics. I continued to be monitored closely to ensure my well-being as I adjusted to life outside the womb.
options: A. Respiratory support with mechanical ventilation is the first-line management B. The condition is benign and self-limiting, requiring no specific treatment C. This is hard to distinguish from pneumonia and sepsis so empirical antibiotics are given for 48 hours after birth until sepsis is ruled out D. Surfactant deficiency is the underlying cause, so surfactant therapy is required E. This is most likely transient tachypnea of the newborn and requires no antibiotics F. Tachypnea in this case is likely due to a congenital heart defect, so echocardiography is indicated G. ABG is needed to monitor  and it is normal to have CO2 retention H. A chest X-ray must be done immediately to confirm the diagnosis of neonatal pneumonia I. Empirical antifungal therapy should be initiated until fungal sepsis is ruled out J. Oxygen therapy is the mainstay of therapy with  monitoring with SpO2
solution_text: This is hard to distinguish from pneumonia and sepsis so empirical antibiotics are given for 48 hours after birth until sepsis is ruled out
default: Based on the symptoms and clinical findings described, it appears that you were diagnosed with transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN). This condition is common in infants delivered via cesarean section and typically presents with rapid breathing and retractions shortly after birth, without significant distress or cyanosis. The absence of CO2 retention and other concerning signs supports this diagnosis. TTN is usually self-limiting, and close monitoring is appropriate, as most infants recover without the need for specific treatment.
alternative: This is hard to distinguish from pneumonia and sepsis so empirical antibiotics are given for 48 hours after birth until sepsis is ruled out

question:
Over the past year, I underwent evaluation by a pediatric cardiac surgeon due to a congenital heart defect. During this time, five children, including myself, were assessed for similar conditions. All of us exhibited stable vital signs and were receiving appropriate medications. During the examination, a loud holosystolic murmur was noted over the third intercostal space at the left sternal border for each of us.

The surgeon conducted echocardiograms to gain further insight into our heart defects. After reviewing the findings, surgical closure of the defect was recommended for one of the patients. I observed that there were various cases among us, each with different defect sizes and associated complications, which included conditions like pulmonary hypertension and shunting patterns. 

The specific details of each case varied: one child had a muscular defect with a mild left-to-right shunt, another had moderate pulmonary hypertension responsive to medication, while others presented with severe pulmonary vascular disease or bidirectional shunting. The circumstances surrounding our evaluations highlighted the complexities of congenital heart defects and the individualized approach required for treatment recommendations.
options: A. A 5-year-old boy with a 3-mm muscular defect and mild left-to-right shunt B. An 18-month-old boy with a 6-mm defect and moderate pulmonary hypertension responsive to vasodilators C. A 7-year-old boy with an 11-mm muscular defect and severe pulmonary vascular disease that is unresponsive to pulmonary vasodilators D. A 6-year-old boy with a 7-mm defect and bidirectional shunting E. A 3-year-old girl with a 2-mm perimembranous defect and normal pulmonary pressures F. A 15-month-old girl with a 4.5-mm defect showing decreasing size on follow-up imaging G. A 5-year-old girl with a 2-mm membranous defect and a left-to-right shunt without associated left ventricular dilation H. An 8-month-old girl with a 3-mm defect and normal pulmonary artery pressures I. A 4-year-old girl with multiple small muscular defects (<3mm each) and normal right ventricular pressure J. A 9-month-old boy with a 4-mm muscular defect with pulmonary hypertension
solution_text: A 9-month-old boy with a 4-mm muscular defect with pulmonary hypertension
default: It sounds like you and the other children underwent thorough evaluations for congenital heart defects, which can vary significantly in severity and implications. The presence of a loud holosystolic murmur suggests a significant defect, often associated with conditions like ventricular septal defects (VSD). The decision for surgical intervention typically depends on factors such as the size of the defect, the degree of shunting, and the presence of complications like pulmonary hypertension. Each case's unique characteristics necessitate a tailored approach to treatment, emphasizing the importance of individualized care in managing congenital heart conditions.
alternative: A 9-month-old boy with a 4-mm muscular defect with pulmonary hypertension

question:
I am a 43-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C and current intravenous drug use. Recently, I experienced 5 days of fever, chills, headache, and severe back pain. When I sought medical attention, my temperature was recorded at 100.6°F, my blood pressure was 109/56 mmHg, my pulse was 94 beats per minute, and my respirations were 18 per minute. During the examination, I appeared thin and was sweating profusely. The doctor noted that I had pinpoint pupils, poor dental health, and track marks on my arms and legs.

A high-pitched systolic murmur was detected, which was loudest near the left sternal border and increased with inspiration. I was admitted to the hospital, where I was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. Twelve hours later, one of the blood cultures taken returned positive for Staphylococcus aureus. 

Following this, my medical team discussed the next steps for confirming the diagnosis. They considered several options, including whether to repeat blood cultures or perform additional imaging. The focus was on determining the most appropriate actions to take based on my current condition and the findings from the initial cultures.
options: A. Repeat blood cultures only if the patient develops new symptoms B. Repeat blood cultures 24 hours after initial cultures were drawn C. Initiate antifungal therapy and defer repeat blood cultures D. Do not repeat blood cultures E. Perform transthoracic echocardiography before repeating blood cultures F. Repeat blood cultures 48 hours after initial antibiotics are started G. Perform transesophageal echocardiography immediately H. Repeat blood cultures now I. Order a CT scan of the chest to assess for septic emboli J. Wait for sensitivity results before repeating blood cultures
default:
Based on your symptoms and the positive blood culture for Staphylococcus aureus, the clinical suspicion is for infective endocarditis, particularly given your history of intravenous drug use and the presence of a high-pitched systolic murmur. 

The next appropriate step would be to perform a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) to assess for vegetations on the heart valves, which is crucial for confirming the diagnosis of endocarditis. If the TTE is inconclusive, a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) may be warranted for better visualization. Repeating blood cultures is also important to monitor for persistent bacteremia and to guide antibiotic therapy, but the echocardiogram is essential for diagnosing potential cardiac involvement.

question:
At 27 weeks into my first pregnancy, I attended a routine prenatal visit. Overall, my pregnancy had been uncomplicated, although I had been experiencing increasing fatigue and mild swelling in my legs. My medical history includes epilepsy, which I manage with lamotrigine. I also learned that my sister had experienced preeclampsia during her pregnancy.

During the visit, I was informed that I was up-to-date on my immunizations and that I do not use tobacco or alcohol. The physical examination showed a temperature of 36.1°C, a pulse of 88 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was recorded at 128/78 mm Hg. It was noted that the size of my uterus was appropriate for my gestational age, but I had bilateral 1+ pitting edema in my ankles.

After the examination, I was informed that further steps were being considered to ensure my health and the health of my baby. The healthcare team discussed the most appropriate next steps in my management following their assessment.
options: A. Admit the patient for observation and preeclampsia workup B. Reassure the patient and schedule a follow-up appointment C. Initiate corticosteroid therapy for fetal lung maturity D. Order coagulation studies and liver chemistries E. Order urine dipstick and ambulatory blood pressure monitoring F. Initiate low-dose aspirin therapy G. Repeat platelet count and peripheral smear in 2 weeks H. Perform a biophysical profile to assess fetal status I. Perform a non-stress test to assess fetal well-being J. Measure serum protein and albumin levels
solution_text: Reassure the patient and schedule a follow-up appointment
default:
Given your history of epilepsy, family history of preeclampsia, and current symptoms of fatigue and mild swelling, the healthcare team may consider monitoring for signs of preeclampsia, especially since you are at an increased risk due to your sister's experience. They might recommend regular blood pressure checks, urine tests for protein, and possibly additional blood tests to assess liver and kidney function. 

Additionally, they may discuss lifestyle modifications to manage swelling and fatigue, and ensure that your lamotrigine levels are monitored closely throughout your pregnancy. Regular follow-up appointments will be essential to monitor both your health and the baby's development.
alternative: Reassure the patient and schedule a follow-up appointment

question:
I was born as a male at 34 weeks gestation and was assessed in the NICU due to breathing difficulties. My mother, 33 years old and generally healthy, experienced polyhydramnios during her pregnancy. At one and five minutes after birth, I received Apgar scores of 6 and 8, respectively. 

In the NICU, the staff observed that I had excessive oral secretions and experienced periodic oxygen desaturation. My vital signs indicated a temperature of 100.8°F, blood pressure of 100/55 mmHg, a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. During the clinical examination, signs of respiratory distress were noted, including intercostal retractions and bilateral rales upon lung auscultation. Additionally, my abdomen appeared moderately distended.

A chest X-ray revealed that the nasogastric tube was coiling within my esophagus. Given these observations, the medical team determined that further investigation into specific conditions was necessary to better understand my situation.
options: A. Pyloric stenosis B. Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula C. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia D. Laryngeal web E. Ventricular septal defect F. Bronchogenic cyst G. Hirschsprung disease H. Choanal atresia I. Meconium ileus J. Duodenal atresia
default: Based on the provided information, the clinical presentation suggests a possible diagnosis of esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). The excessive oral secretions, respiratory distress, and the finding of the nasogastric tube coiling in the esophagus are indicative of this condition. The distended abdomen may also suggest that air is entering the gastrointestinal tract through a fistula. Further diagnostic evaluation, such as a contrast study or endoscopy, would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the condition.

question:
I was taken to the emergency department after my mother noticed I had a sore throat and was having difficulty breathing. My symptoms started the night before and seemed to worsen quickly. I am usually a healthy 5-year-old, and I keep up with all my vaccinations while taking a daily multivitamin.

When we arrived at the hospital, the staff recorded my temperature, which was 103°F. They also checked my blood pressure, pulse, and breathing rate. I was feeling very ill and was drooling, leaning forward to find a more comfortable position to breathe. I struggled to communicate and was visibly uncomfortable during the examination, making it hard for the doctors to perform an oral exam.

The healthcare team seemed concerned about my condition and was evaluating the possible causes of my symptoms. They noted my high fever, difficulty in breathing, and overall distress. The focus was on identifying the most likely infectious cause of my illness.
options: A. Haemophilus influenzae B. Streptococcus pneumoniae C. Parainfluenza virus D. Staphylococcus aureus E. Group A Streptococcus F. Adenovirus G. Mycoplasma pneumoniae H. Epstein-Barr virus I. Corynebacterium diphtheriae J. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
default: Based on your symptoms—high fever, difficulty breathing, drooling, and leaning forward to breathe—there is a strong concern for epiglottitis, which is an inflammation of the epiglottis that can obstruct the airway. This condition is often caused by bacterial infection, particularly Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), especially in unvaccinated children. Immediate medical intervention is critical to secure the airway and provide appropriate treatment.

question:
I am an 18-year-old male who recently underwent surgery for a craniopharyngioma, which was discovered while investigating my delayed puberty and panhypopituitarism. I returned for a follow-up evaluation two months post-surgery. Overall, I feel generally well, but I have been experiencing intermittent fevers that reach up to 39°C, along with an increased appetite.

My current medication regimen includes daily levothyroxine, hydrocortisone taken in the morning and afternoon, desmopressin nasal spray, and intramuscular testosterone injections. During my examination, my temperature was noted at 38.8°C, with a heart rate of 97 beats per minute and blood pressure at 129/88 mm Hg. My body mass index (BMI) was measured at 34.2. The craniotomy scar appears well-healed without any complications, and there is no sign of nuchal rigidity. The rest of my physical exam was normal.

Recent tests, including two sets of blood cultures, urinalysis, and chest radiograph, returned negative results. An MRI of my head showed expected post-surgical changes. 

Given these circumstances, I am left to consider the potential causes of my fever, which could range from medication-induced effects to possible hypothalamic dysfunction or other post-operative complications.
options: A. Medication-induced fever B. Residual tumor progression C. Drug reaction D. Hypothalamic dysfunction E. Occult postoperative infection F. Autonomic dysregulation G. Autoimmune hypophysitis H. Overrepletion of thyroid hormone I. Inadequate glucocorticoid replacement J. Meningeal irritation
default:
Given your recent surgery for craniopharyngioma and the symptoms you're experiencing, the intermittent fevers could be attributed to several factors. 

1. **Hypothalamic Dysfunction**: Since the hypothalamus regulates body temperature, any disruption from the surgery could lead to dysregulation and fever.

2. **Infection**: Although your blood cultures and imaging are negative, it's still possible to have a localized infection that hasn't been detected yet, especially considering your surgical history.

3. **Medication Effects**: Some medications, including hydrocortisone, can cause side effects that might include fever. 

4. **Post-operative Inflammatory Response**: It's not uncommon to have a transient inflammatory response after surgery, which could manifest as

question:
I am a 65-year-old man who recently experienced a series of concerning symptoms over the past four months. I developed a low-grade fever and a sense of malaise that persisted throughout this period. I noticed a significant weight loss of 9 kg (20 lb) and felt an extreme level of fatigue that affected my daily activities.

During a medical consultation, my temperature was recorded at 38.1°C (100.6°F), and my vital signs showed a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, a pulse of 102 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 138/78 mm Hg. Upon physical examination, my doctor detected a new onset 2/6 holosystolic murmur, which was loudest in the apical area of my precordium.

I have a medical history that includes a mitral valve replacement five years ago. Given my symptoms and findings, my doctor has been considering the potential causes of my condition.
options: A. *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* B. *Bartonella henselae* C. HACEK group organisms D. *Candida albicans* E. Beta-hemolytic streptococci F. *Staphylococcus aureus* G. Coagulase-negative *Staphylococcus spp.* H. *Pseudomonas* aeruginosa I. *Streptococcus bovis* J. *Enterococcus*
default: Based on your symptoms and medical history, particularly the new holosystolic murmur and your history of mitral valve replacement, your doctor is likely considering the possibility of prosthetic valve endocarditis. This condition can present with fever, malaise, weight loss, and fatigue, especially in patients with a history of valve replacement. The murmur suggests possible regurgitation or infection of the valve. It is crucial to undergo further evaluation, including blood cultures and echocardiography, to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate treatment.

question:
I am a 57-year-old male who recently went to the emergency department after experiencing a week of weakness and subjective fever. My medical history includes IV drug use, hepatitis C, atrial fibrillation, cirrhosis, alcohol dependence, obesity, and depression. Upon examination, I had a temperature of 102°F, blood pressure of 157/98 mmHg, and a pulse of 110 beats per minute. My respiratory rate was 17 breaths per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 98% while breathing room air. I felt fatigued and exhibited signs of diffuse jaundice.

During the physical exam, the healthcare provider noted bibasilar crackles in my lungs and found my abdomen distended with dullness to percussion and tenderness. I was admitted to the hospital and treated with piperacillin-tazobactam. By the fourth day, I was afebrile, my pulse had decreased to 92 beats per minute, and the abdominal tenderness had lessened, although the jaundice persisted.

The nursing staff reported that I had bleeding from two peripheral IV sites, which required pressure to control, and I developed new bruises on my arms and legs. These symptoms prompted further evaluation to understand the underlying cause of my condition.
options: A. Fibrinolysis activation due to liver failure B. Vitamin K deficiency due to liver dysfunction C. Diffuse activation of the coagulation cascade D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) E. Platelet dysfunction secondary to sepsis F. Decreased production of coagulation factors G. Immune-mediated platelet destruction H. Hypersplenism causing thrombocytopenia I. Decreased metabolism of an anticoagulant J. Bacterial destruction
default:
Given your medical history and recent symptoms, the bleeding from IV sites and new bruising suggest a possible coagulopathy, which is common in patients with cirrhosis due to impaired liver function. The persistent jaundice indicates ongoing liver dysfunction, likely related to your hepatitis C and cirrhosis. 

The combination of fever, abdominal distension, and respiratory symptoms could indicate an infection, possibly spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) given your cirrhosis. The treatment with piperacillin-tazobactam suggests a concern for a bacterial infection, which may have improved your fever and abdominal tenderness.

The new bleeding and bruising could be due to thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) often seen in cirr

question:
I am a 59-year-old male who recently visited my primary care physician due to feelings of fatigue. Although I generally consider myself healthy, I've noticed some concerning changes, including unexpected weight loss, abdominal pain, and a persistent sense of fatigue. 

My medical history includes anxiety and diabetes, and I previously suffered a foot fracture after tripping. Additionally, I had a recent cold that caused me to miss work for a week. My current medications include metformin, insulin, buspirone, vitamin D, calcium, and sodium docusate. 

During my appointment, the doctor noted my vital signs: a temperature of 99.5°F, blood pressure at 150/100 mmHg, a pulse of 90 beats per minute, and respirations at 18 per minute, with oxygen saturation at 98% on room air. The physical exam showed that I appeared calm, though a mild systolic murmur was detected in the left upper sternal region. Otherwise, the exam was unremarkable.

Given these symptoms and findings, my physician is considering various diagnoses related to my elevated leukocyte count and other factors. I am awaiting further evaluation to determine the most likely cause of my symptoms.
options: A. Myelodysplastic syndrome B. Polycythemia vera C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia D. Primary myelofibrosis E. Leukemoid reaction F. Essential thrombocythemia G. Chronic myeloid leukemia H. Acute myeloid leukemia I. Chronic myelogenous leukemia J. Paraneoplastic leukocytosis
default:
Given your symptoms of fatigue, unexpected weight loss, abdominal pain, and elevated leukocyte count, along with your medical history of diabetes and anxiety, several potential diagnoses could be considered. The combination of these factors raises concern for possible underlying conditions such as an infection, malignancy, or metabolic issues related to your diabetes.

The mild systolic murmur and elevated blood pressure may also suggest cardiovascular involvement, which could be related to your overall health status. It's crucial to follow up on the further evaluations your physician has planned, which may include blood tests, imaging studies, or referrals to specialists, to pinpoint the exact cause of your symptoms. In the meantime, maintaining regular communication with your healthcare provider about any changes in your condition is essential.

question:
I was assessed in the labor and delivery unit shortly after my birth, which took place at 37 weeks of gestation. I experienced feeding difficulties, rapid breathing, and had a bluish-grey skin discoloration. My mother, who had irregular prenatal care, reported no drug use during her pregnancy.

Upon examination, my temperature was recorded at 98.2 ºF, with a blood pressure of 70/40 mmHg and a pulse rate of 170 beats per minute. My respiratory rate was noted to be 56 breaths per minute. The physical examination indicated that I was lethargic and cyanotic, and there was evidence of jugular venous distention.

During chest auscultation, the medical team observed tachypnea, a single second heart sound, and a continuous murmur. A chest X-ray revealed reduced pulmonary vascular markings, while an electrocardiogram showed tall P-waves in lead II and low-amplitude R-waves in leads V1-V3. 

These findings led the medical team to consider possible congenital cardiac anomalies that could explain my symptoms.
options: A. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return B. Complete transposition of the great arteries C. Isolated opening in membranous interventricular septum D. Persistent truncus arteriosus E. Enclosed muscular floor within the right atrium F. Pulmonary venous drainage into the right atrium G. Proximal atrialization of the right ventricle H. Severe tricuspid valve regurgitation I. Right ventricular hypertrophy with pulmonary stenosis J. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
solution_text: Enclosed muscular floor within the right atrium
default:
Based on the symptoms and findings described, the most likely diagnosis is **tricuspid atresia**. The key indicators supporting this diagnosis include:

- **Cyanosis and lethargy**: Suggestive of inadequate oxygenation.
- **Jugular venous distention**: Indicates right heart failure or volume overload.
- **Continuous murmur**: Often associated with collateral circulation or shunting.
- **Chest X-ray findings**: Reduced pulmonary vascular markings suggest decreased blood flow to the lungs, which is consistent with tricuspid atresia.
- **ECG findings**: Tall P-waves in lead II and low-amplitude R-waves in leads V1-V3 can indicate right atrial enlargement and poor right ventricular
alternative: Enclosed muscular floor within the right atrium

question:
During my recent review of various medical conditions, I focused on those linked to bone enlargement. I explored several options, including lytic Paget disease, osteochondroma, osteoid osteoma, fibrous dysplasia, melorheostosis, Type II neurofibromatosis, hyperparathyroidism, giant cell tumor, osteopetrosis, and aneurysmal bone cyst. Each condition presented unique characteristics, but I aimed to identify the specific one associated with bone enlargement.

As I analyzed the information, I noted that lytic Paget disease is known for its impact on bone structure, causing enlargement and deformities. In contrast, osteochondroma is a benign growth that can also lead to changes in bone size. I considered osteoid osteoma and fibrous dysplasia as well, but their primary effects differ from pure enlargement. Melorheostosis and Type II neurofibromatosis have distinct presentations that do not solely focus on enlargement. Hyperparathyroidism can lead to bone changes, but its overall impact is more generalized. The giant cell tumor and osteopetrosis also came to mind, but their associations with enlargement vary.

Ultimately, my inquiry led me to recognize the complexity of these conditions and their effects on bone structure, particularly the notable enlargement seen in lytic Paget disease and osteochondroma.
options: A. Lytic Paget disease B. Osteochondroma C. Osteoid osteoma D. Fibrous dysplasia E. Melorheostosis F. Type II neurofibromatosis G. Hyperparathyroidism H. Giant cell tumor I. Osteopetrosis J. Aneurysmal bone cyst
default: The condition most specifically associated with bone enlargement is **lytic Paget disease**. It is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlarged and deformed bones. While osteochondroma can also cause changes in bone size, Paget disease is more prominently linked to significant enlargement and structural changes.

question:
I am a 45-year-old man who recently experienced a 2-day history of headache and exertional breathlessness. During this time, I had two episodes of vomiting and noticed that I was unable to urinate. For the past two years, I have been dealing with progressive pain and stiffness in my fingers. I do not have a history of serious illness, and I do not take any medications, smoke, or use alcohol.

When I sought medical attention, I felt moderately distressed. My temperature was recorded at 37.2°C (98.9°F), my pulse was 88 beats per minute, and my respirations were at 24 per minute. My blood pressure was measured at 170/100 mm Hg, and my oxygen saturation on room air was 91%. The physical examination revealed pallor, 2+ pretibial edema, and jugular venous distention. There was also coarse and thickened skin on my arms, chest, and upper back, along with diffuse hyperpigmentation and hypopigmented patches with perifollicular hypopigmentation. I had contractures in my proximal interphalangeal joints. Upon auscultation of my chest, diffuse crackles were noted, with dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds at the lung bases. My cardiac examination showed normal S1 and S2 with an S3 gallop at the apex.
options: A. Elevated anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies B. Decreased serum complement concentration C. Increased anti-CCP antibody titers D. Increased anticentromere antibody titers E. Decreased serum haptoglobin concentration F. Increased serum aldosterone levels G. Elevated anti-Scl-70 antibodies H. Elevated anti-PM/Scl antibodies I. Increased serum erythropoietin levels J. Increased serum ferritin concentration
default: The symptoms and findings you describe are suggestive of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), particularly the limited form, which can lead to pulmonary complications and renal involvement. The progressive pain and stiffness in your fingers, along with skin changes (coarse, thickened skin, hyperpigmentation, and contractures), are characteristic of this condition. The exertional breathlessness, crackles on lung auscultation, and signs of heart failure (S3 gallop) indicate possible pulmonary fibrosis and cardiac involvement. The inability to urinate and hypertension may suggest renal crisis, which can occur in scleroderma. Immediate evaluation and management by a rheumatologist and possibly a nephrologist are warranted.

question:
I took my 2-month-old son to his routine health maintenance visit. During the examination, the healthcare provider noted that his growth and development were on track, with his height and weight at the 50th percentile, which was consistent with previous measurements. However, I learned that his head circumference had increased significantly to the 90th percentile from the 50th percentile recorded at his newborn visit. 

The provider observed that his head appeared elongated and narrow, featuring a prominent occiput and broad forehead. Importantly, there were no facial dysmorphic features present, and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. 

The healthcare provider discussed the next steps, considering the changes in my son’s head circumference. I was presented with several options for initial management, including increased time in the prone position while monitored, measuring parental head circumferences to check for familial macrocephaly, referral to a physical therapist for positional head shape issues, and other evaluations such as cranial ultrasound or MRI. 

Ultimately, I was advised that the most appropriate course of action would be to observe his head circumference and plan for a reevaluation in one month, unless any concerning symptoms presented themselves in the meantime. This approach gave me reassurance while we monitored his growth.
options: A. Increased time in the prone position while awake and monitored B. Measurement of parental head circumferences to assess for familial macrocephaly C. Referral to a physical therapist to address positional head shape deformities D. Cranial ultrasound to assess for hydrocephalus E. MRI of the brain to evaluate intracranial structures F. Observation with no further intervention unless symptoms worsen G. Reevaluation of head circumference in one month H. Referral to a pediatric endocrinologist for evaluation of growth abnormalities I. Referral to craniofacial specialists J. Referral for genetic testing
default: The significant increase in your son's head circumference, along with the observed head shape changes, raises concerns for potential conditions such as positional plagiocephaly or other cranial abnormalities. The healthcare provider's recommendation to monitor his head circumference and plan for a reevaluation in one month is appropriate, as it allows for careful observation of any further changes. This approach balances the need for vigilance with reassurance, especially in the absence of concerning symptoms or dysmorphic features. If any unusual signs develop, further imaging or referrals can be pursued as needed.

question:
I am a 15-year-old male who experienced a fall during a skateboarding competition, which led to a persistent sensation that I can only describe as "a funny feeling in my head." After the accident, I underwent a neurological workup, both immediately and several weeks later, but the results were negative, and I did not report any other symptoms.

During a physical examination, I was not in acute distress, and there were no visible head lacerations or abrasions. Additionally, there was no evidence of skull fractures. The neurological examination indicated that my cranial nerves II through XII were intact. 

However, during an osteopathic structural examination, it was noted that the greater wings of my sphenoid appeared to be deviated caudad, which gave them a posterior feel. This finding has led to further consideration of what might be affecting me, but I remain focused on understanding the nature of this persistent sensation in my head.
options: A. Suboccipital strain B. Cranial base dysfunction C. Compression D. Superior vertical strain E. Lateral strain F. Sidebending rotation G. Inferior vertical strain H. Posterior cranial base strain I. Torsion J. Sphenobasilar synchondrosis compression
default:
The "funny feeling" in your head after the fall could be related to a few factors, especially given the findings from your osteopathic examination. The deviation of the greater wings of the sphenoid may suggest some cranial strain or tension, which can sometimes lead to sensations like pressure, dizziness, or altered perception. 

Even though your neurological workup was negative, it's important to consider that post-concussion symptoms can sometimes manifest subtly and may not always show up on standard tests. It might be beneficial to explore osteopathic treatment options, such as cranial manipulation, which could help alleviate any tension or misalignment contributing to your symptoms. Additionally, monitoring your symptoms over time and ensuring you have adequate rest and recovery is crucial. If the sensation persists

question:
I am a 70-year-old male who has been experiencing fatigue for the past eight months. Previously, I was able to walk two miles daily, but now I find myself fatigued after less than half a mile. Climbing just one flight of stairs leaves me short of breath. My medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis, for which I take lisinopril, aspirin, and occasionally use Tylenol for pain relief.

I have not noticed any weight loss, and I do not see blood in my stool or urine, nor do I have dark stools. The last time I had a colonoscopy was eight years ago, during which benign polyps were removed. 

When my vital signs were taken, my temperature was recorded at 37.2°C (98.9°F), my pulse was 110 beats per minute, my respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, and my blood pressure was 132/87 mmHg. During the physical examination, the doctor noted conjunctival pallor, pale nail beds, and dry skin. Although my lungs were clear upon examination, I was found to have tachycardia with a regular rhythm. The abdominal exam appeared normal. 

Given these symptoms and findings, I am now considering the most appropriate next step in managing my condition.
options: A. CT scan abdomen B. Capsule endoscopy C. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) D. Reticulocyte count analysis E. Packed red blood cell transfusion F. Colonoscopy G. Bone marrow biopsy H. Oral iron supplementation I. Peripheral blood smear J. IV iron supplementation
default: Given your symptoms of fatigue, shortness of breath, tachycardia, and physical findings of pallor, it is important to evaluate for anemia, which could explain your fatigue and exertional dyspnea. The next appropriate step in managing your condition would be to perform a complete blood count (CBC) to assess your hemoglobin levels and other blood parameters. This will help determine if anemia is present and guide further management.

question:
I am a 65-year-old woman who recently experienced mild shortness of breath and a chronic, nonproductive cough. I have generally been in good health, have never smoked, and have completed all recommended cancer screenings for my age. 

When I sought medical attention, my vital signs were normal, and my oxygen saturation was measured at 95% while breathing room air. A chest X-ray was performed, which showed a moderate left pleural effusion but no additional abnormalities.

To further investigate, I underwent a procedure called thoracentesis. This procedure yielded a thin, light-green fluid. The subsequent analysis of the fluid provided several parameters, and while the Gram stain and acid-fast bacilli smear did not show any organisms, the cytology revealed slender, elongated, spindle-shaped cells.

I am now considering what additional physical examination finding might be present in my case. Given the circumstances surrounding my symptoms and the results of the thoracentesis, I reflect on the potential physical findings that could be relevant to my condition.
options: A. Sclerodactyly with skin tightening B. Joint hypermobility with skin hyperextensibility C. Gottron's papules over the knuckles D. Raynaud's phenomenon with digital ulcers E. Scattered, seborrheic keratoses over the chest and back F. Clubbing of the digits G. Synovitis of the metacarpophalangeal joints and subcutaneous nodules H. Erythema nodosum on the shins I. Morning stiffness in the proximal interphalangeal joints J. Butterfly rash across the nasal bridge
solution_text: Synovitis of the metacarpophalangeal joints and subcutaneous nodules
default:
Given your symptoms, the presence of a moderate left pleural effusion, and the cytology findings of slender, elongated, spindle-shaped cells, it is likely that you may have a pleural effusion related to a malignancy, possibly mesothelioma or another type of cancer. 

In terms of additional physical examination findings, you might expect to find decreased breath sounds on the left side upon auscultation of the lungs, as well as dullness to percussion over the area of the effusion. These findings would be consistent with the presence of fluid in the pleural space. Additionally, you may have signs of respiratory distress or use of accessory muscles if the shortness of breath worsens.
alternative: Synovitis of the metacarpophalangeal joints and subcutaneous nodules

question:
I am a 75-year-old man with a medical history that includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and coronary artery disease. Over the past two months, I have experienced progressively worsening shortness of breath. I have a significant smoking history, totaling 45 pack-years, and I briefly lived outside the U.S. during my military service in Germany.

During my recent examination, I was afebrile with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. My blood pressure measured 108/73 mm Hg, and my oxygen saturation was 88% on room air. I felt uncomfortable and was breathing rapidly. The examination revealed diminished breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the lower third of my left lung field, while my right lung sounded clear.

A chest CT with intravenous contrast identified a large left pleural effusion without pulmonary parenchymal abnormalities. A diagnostic thoracentesis was performed, yielding 1400 mL of bloody fluid. The analyses of the pleural fluid showed various cell counts, but tests for malignancy and infections returned negative.

Given these findings, I am now considering the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of my pleural effusion.
options: A. Pleural fluid amylase measurement B. Positron emission tomography (PET) scan C. Closed pleural biopsy D. Serum protein electrophoresis E. Bronchoscopy F. Interferon-gamma release assay of blood G. Repeat thoracentesis with cytopathologic study H. Pleural fluid flow cytometry I. Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) J. Echocardiography
default: Given your history and the findings from the thoracentesis, the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of your pleural effusion would be to perform a pleural biopsy. This can help assess for potential malignancy or other underlying conditions that may not have been identified through cytology or infection tests.

question:
I am a 9-year-old female who recently experienced shortness of breath and new-onset cyanosis. My medical history includes dextrocardia, a double inlet left ventricle with malposition of the great arteries, and pulmonary atresia. I also had an extracardiac fenestrated Fontan procedure and a left pulmonary artery patch augmentation. 

During my examination, my vital signs indicated a saturation level of 81% and a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute. The physical exam revealed tachycardia, a normal S1 heart sound, and a single S2 heart sound. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus rhythm, and an echocardiogram indicated normal systemic left ventricular systolic function.

Given the new onset of cyanosis, my healthcare team considered additional testing to diagnose the underlying cause. They evaluated several options, including various laboratory tests and imaging studies to gain further insight into my condition. The focus was to determine the most appropriate diagnostic approach to address my recent symptoms effectively.
options: A. A BNP level of 150 pg/mL B. A subcostal echocardiographic image demonstrating a mean gradient of 3 mmHg through the Fontan conduit C. A D-dimer level of 250 ng/mL D. A chest X-ray showing normal pulmonary vasculature E. A CT angiogram showing patent Fontan pathway F. An albumin of 1.8 G. An activated protein C resistance ratio of 0.3 H. A protein S level of 85% I. An antithrombin III activity of 95% J. A cardiac catheterization showing mean pulmonary artery pressure of 15 mmHg
solution_text: An activated protein C resistance ratio of 0.3
default: Given your complex congenital heart history and the recent onset of cyanosis and shortness of breath, the most appropriate diagnostic approach would likely involve a chest X-ray and possibly a CT angiogram of the chest. These imaging studies can help assess for any acute changes, such as pulmonary artery obstruction, shunting, or other complications related to your previous surgeries. Additionally, laboratory tests, including arterial blood gases, can provide insight into your oxygenation status and help guide further management.
alternative: An activated protein C resistance ratio of 0.3

question:
I am a 28-year-old man who visited an osteopathic clinic due to recurrent migraine headaches that I have been experiencing for the past three months. I have not suffered any trauma during this period. I found that medications provided only temporary relief, which led me to explore osteopathic manipulative treatment as a potential option.

During the physical examination, it was identified that I have a strain at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS), and the sacral base was noted to be tilted anteriorly. This examination prompted further evaluation to understand the underlying issues better. While I am aware of the various potential findings that could arise from this evaluation, I remain focused on finding a treatment that alleviates my symptoms effectively.
options: A. Decreased anteroposterior diameter of the head B. External rotation of the parietal and temporal bones C. Compression of the fourth ventricle D. Internal rotation of the parietal and temporal bones E. Widening of the transverse diameter of the cranium F. Increased cranial rhythmic impulse amplitude G. Sacral base posteriorly tilted H. Flattened occiput with posterior displacement I. Increased anteroposterior diameter of the head J. Cephalad deviation of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis
solution_text: Internal rotation of the parietal and temporal bones
default:
Given your symptoms and the findings of a strain at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis and anteriorly tilted sacral base, osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) may help alleviate your migraine headaches. OMT can address the cranial and sacral dysfunctions, potentially improving cranial circulation and reducing tension in the surrounding structures. 

It's essential to work closely with your osteopathic physician to develop a tailored treatment plan that may include OMT techniques aimed at restoring normal function and alignment. Additionally, consider discussing lifestyle factors, stress management, and any potential triggers for your migraines to enhance your overall treatment approach.
alternative: Internal rotation of the parietal and temporal bones

question:
At my 4-month-old son’s routine well-child check, I shared some concerns with the pediatrician. We have been struggling to wean him from nighttime feedings. After about 3-4 hours without feeding, he becomes extremely distressed and can only be calmed by being fed.

During the growth assessment, I learned that his length has declined from the 25th percentile to the 5th percentile, while his weight has remained steady at the 25th percentile. The physical examination revealed distinctive facial fullness, a significantly distended abdomen, and thin limbs. The pediatrician noted that the edge of his liver extends to the iliac crest, although his spleen did not appear enlarged.

A blood sample was taken, and I noticed a characteristic milky white layer forming on the surface. The pediatrician discussed various possible diagnoses and mentioned several conditions that could explain my son’s symptoms. I left the appointment with a better understanding of his condition and the next steps we might need to take.
options: A. Prader-Willi syndrome B. Congenital hyperinsulinism C. Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency D. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase deficiency E. Gaucher disease F. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency G. Glycogen storage disease type 1 H. Tay-Sachs disease I. Familial hypercholesterolemia J. Niemann-Pick disease type A
default: Based on the symptoms you've described—failure to thrive, distinctive facial fullness, abdominal distension, thin limbs, and the presence of a milky white layer in the blood sample—your son may be experiencing a condition related to metabolic disorders, such as a possible lipid storage disorder or a malabsorption issue. The milky layer suggests hyperlipidemia, which can occur in conditions like Wolman disease or other metabolic syndromes. It's crucial to follow up with the pediatrician for further testing and a definitive diagnosis, as early intervention can be key in managing these conditions.

question:
I am a 15-year-old girl with a history of phenylketonuria (PKU), which was diagnosed through newborn screening. At birth, my confirmatory phenylalanine level was significantly elevated. Throughout my early childhood, my average phenylalanine level was maintained within the treatment range. 

During a recent well visit, I expressed my discomfort with consuming my phenylalanine-free formula at school. I find its strong odor off-putting, and the lack of refrigeration options makes it difficult to manage. I am considering purchasing meals from the school cafeteria and transitioning to a vegetarian diet. 

I am aware that my dietary choices could have potential effects on my health, especially given my PKU. I am particularly interested in understanding how an unrestricted vegetarian diet might impact my condition. I remain cautious about the implications, such as possible cognitive effects or other health issues that could arise from not adhering strictly to my dietary restrictions. As I navigate this decision, I aim to find a balance that accommodates my lifestyle while managing my health effectively.
options: A. Hyperammonemia and acute mental status changes B. Mild cognitive impairment with preserved executive function C. Progressive vision loss and retinal degeneration D. Reversible neurological symptoms without long-term consequences E. None — a diet free of animal protein is sufficient to provide metabolic control F. Mood dysregulation, inattentiveness, and hyperactivity G. Growth delay and osteoporosis H. Anxiety and depression without cognitive changes I. Cognitive decline and irreversible demyelination J. Gastrointestinal symptoms and malabsorption
default:
Transitioning to a vegetarian diet while managing phenylketonuria (PKU) requires careful consideration. A vegetarian diet can be high in protein, particularly from sources like legumes, nuts, and dairy, which are rich in phenylalanine. Consuming these foods without proper management could lead to elevated phenylalanine levels, potentially impacting cognitive function and overall health.

It's crucial to maintain strict dietary control to prevent complications associated with PKU. If you're considering a vegetarian diet, consult with a dietitian who specializes in PKU. They can help you create a balanced meal plan that meets your nutritional needs while keeping your phenylalanine levels in check. You might also explore low-protein vegetarian options and fortified foods that align with your dietary

question:
I am a 64-year-old male who arrived at the emergency department via ambulance after experiencing troubling symptoms that began two hours earlier. I had difficulty speaking, right facial numbness, and weakness in my right arm and leg. My medical history includes type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and I have a 25 pack-year smoking history. I take medications such as insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin.

Upon arrival, my vital signs were taken: my temperature was normal, heart rate was 80 beats per minute, respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, and my blood pressure was 140 over 85. During the physical examination, I was alert and able to follow commands; however, I could not correctly identify the current month or my age. The examination revealed a right facial droop, right-sided limb drift, and diminished sensation on my right side, but there was no eye deviation.

The medical team began to assess my condition and determine the next steps for management.
options: A. Carotid duplex ultrasound B. Computerized tomography (CT) of the head C. Intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) D. Aspirin E. Fingerstick glucose level F. Electrocardiogram (ECG) G. Neurological consultation H. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain I. Echocardiogram J. Complete blood count with coagulation profile
default:
Based on your symptoms and medical history, it appears you may be experiencing a stroke, likely an ischemic stroke given your risk factors (diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking history). The acute onset of difficulty speaking, right facial numbness, and weakness in your right arm and leg are classic signs.

The medical team will likely perform a CT scan of the head to rule out hemorrhagic stroke and assess for ischemic changes. If an ischemic stroke is confirmed and you are within the appropriate time window (typically within 4.5 hours of symptom onset), they may consider administering tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) to dissolve the clot. 

Additionally, they will monitor your vital signs and neurological status closely

question:
I am a 34-year-old female who went to the emergency department due to chest discomfort. I described the sensation as feeling like something was stuck in my chest. This was the third episode I experienced this month; the previous incidents occurred while I was at the gym and consuming sports drinks. Those episodes resolved after I rested briefly. 

The current episode was triggered by news about my father's heart attack and lasted approximately 15 minutes. Over the past few months, I have also had intermittent difficulties with swallowing. I did not experience any palpitations, sweating, or breathing problems during this event. 

My medical history includes obesity and chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which I manage with daily omeprazole. My mother has scleroderma. I drink alcohol socially, but I do not smoke or use illicit drugs. 

When I arrived at the emergency department, my vital signs were stable, with a temperature of 98.4°F, blood pressure of 143/82 mmHg, a pulse of 89 beats per minute, and respirations of 16 breaths per minute. The physical examination indicated mild discomfort, but I was not in acute distress. My heart sounds were normal, and my lung fields were clear.
options: A. Nuclear stress test B. Esophageal manometry C. 24-hour pH monitoring D. Esophageal scintigraphy E. High-resolution esophageal ultrasound F. Barium swallow G. Electrocardiogram H. Endoscopy I. Impedance testing J. Chest CT with contrast
default:
Based on your symptoms and medical history, it seems likely that your chest discomfort is related to your chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), especially given the sensation of something being stuck in your chest and the intermittent swallowing difficulties. The episodes occurring during physical activity and after consuming sports drinks may suggest a connection to esophageal irritation or spasms, potentially exacerbated by stress, as indicated by the recent news about your father's heart attack.

While your vital signs are stable and there are no acute distress signs, it’s important to rule out any cardiac issues, especially given your family history. However, the absence of palpitations, sweating, or breathing problems, along with the resolution of symptoms with rest, leans more towards a non-cardiac

question:
I am a 52-year-old African American male who recently visited my primary care physician due to swelling in my legs that began approximately two weeks ago. I could not identify any specific trigger for this swelling. Alongside the edema, I reported experiencing joint pain, headaches, and tingling sensations in my fingers and toes, although I did not believe these symptoms were related to the swelling.

During the examination, my doctor noted that I had significant pitting edema in both legs. My medical history includes well-controlled rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, and hypertension. I did not report any shortness of breath, back pain, or skull pain during the visit.

As part of the diagnostic process, a chest radiograph was performed, which revealed mild cardiac enlargement. A urinalysis showed a high level of protein in my urine, along with casts that appeared cross-like under polarized light. These findings led to a renal biopsy, which demonstrated characteristic features that were also visible only under polarized light.

I am seeking to understand the likely cause of the edema I am experiencing, particularly in relation to my medical history and the results of various tests that have been conducted.
options: A. Elevated levels of IL-6 B. Elevated levels of hemoglobin A1c C. Antibodies to phospholipase A2 receptor D. Increased serum TNF-alpha levels E. Abnormally shaped red blood cells F. Elevated serum complement levels G. Decreased serum albumin with normal globulins H. Anti-nuclear antibodies with homogeneous pattern I. Altered kappa to lambda ratio J. Elevated rheumatoid factor titers
default:
The symptoms and test results you described suggest that the edema in your legs is likely related to nephrotic syndrome, possibly due to underlying kidney disease. The presence of significant pitting edema, proteinuria (high protein levels in urine), and casts observed in the urinalysis, along with the renal biopsy findings, indicate that your kidneys are not functioning properly, leading to fluid retention.

Given your medical history of rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, and hypertension, these conditions can contribute to kidney damage over time, potentially leading to glomerular disease. The characteristic features seen under polarized light in the biopsy may suggest conditions like minimal change disease or focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which are known to cause nephrotic syndrome.

question:
I was taken to the medical office after experiencing progressive abdominal pain that had worsened over the past 24 hours. My father mentioned that I had a history of constipation and had not had a bowel movement for the last 72 hours. I also had three episodes of vomiting since the previous night and was refusing to eat. 

During the examination, the doctor noted that my upper abdomen was distended and made a tympanic sound when tapped. They did not find any abdominal mass, involuntary guarding, or rebound tenderness. My medical and surgical history was unremarkable, with no previous significant health issues. 

The healthcare team discussed my symptoms and the possible underlying causes, considering various conditions that could explain my clinical presentation.
options: A. Hirschsprung disease B. Intestinal lymphoma C. Superior mesenteric artery syndrome D. Chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction E. Volvulus F. Malrotation of the gut G. Pyloric stenosis H. Intussusception I. Meckel diverticulum J. Duodenal web
default: Based on your symptoms of progressive abdominal pain, distension, tympanic sound on percussion, history of constipation, and vomiting, the most likely underlying cause is a bowel obstruction, possibly due to fecal impaction. The absence of an abdominal mass, guarding, or rebound tenderness suggests that there may not be an acute inflammatory process, but the combination of constipation and vomiting indicates a significant gastrointestinal issue that requires further evaluation and management.

question:
At my recent routine well-child checkup, I took my 4-year-old son to the clinic. He started walking when he was 20 months old. During the visit, I noted that he can drink from a cup, but he hasn't yet learned to use silverware. His speech consists of two-word phrases, and he is able to stack four blocks. He can scribble but has not yet been able to draw a circle.

The doctor measured his height and found it to be above the 99th percentile, while his weight was at the 15th percentile. All his vital signs appeared normal. Upon examination, the doctor observed some physical characteristics: he had bilateral inferior lens dislocation, long slender fingers, a high-arched palate, and hyperelastic skin. Notably, when he wrapped one hand around the opposite wrist, his thumb and fifth finger overlapped. 

The doctor mentioned that these findings could suggest an underlying condition, but I didn't get into specifics during the visit. The focus was on understanding my son's developmental milestones and any potential health implications related to these physical features.
options: A. Fibrillin 1 deficiency B. Procollagen peptidase deficiency C. Type I collagen mutation D. Deficiency of pyridoxine-dependent enzymes E. Alpha-1,4-glucosidase deficiency F. Mutation in the FGFR3 gene G. Type V collagen deficiency H. Lysyl hydroxylase deficiency I. Homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency J. Cystathionine synthase deficiency
default: Based on the physical characteristics and developmental milestones you've described, your son may have Marfan syndrome. The key features such as bilateral inferior lens dislocation, long slender fingers, a high-arched palate, hyperelastic skin, and the ability to overlap his thumb and fifth finger are indicative of this connective tissue disorder. It's important to follow up with a geneticist or a specialist for further evaluation and management, as Marfan syndrome can have implications for cardiovascular health and other systems.

question:
I recently visited my primary care clinic for my annual checkup. Four days prior to this appointment, I had a tooth extraction due to an infection and began taking amoxicillin-clavulanate as prescribed. Additionally, I was given hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5 mg tablets, which I have been taking at a dosage of two pills per day for the last two days.

My medical history includes diabetes mellitus, mild gastroesophageal reflux disease, and iron deficiency anemia, which is a result of heavy menstrual periods. The medications I regularly take include metformin, ferrous sulfate, and magnesium hydroxide as needed for my reflux.

During the visit, I reported that I have been feeling well overall. However, I mentioned that I had not had a bowel movement in six days, which is unusual for me. This change in my bowel habits raised concerns about possible contributing factors from my current medications. I am trying to understand which of my medications might be affecting my bowel movement frequency.
options: A. Ferrous sulfate B. Phenformin C. Levofloxacin D. Cefdinir E. Metformin F. Amoxicillin-clavulanate G. Magnesium hydroxide H. Magnesium citrate I. Hydrocodone-acetaminophen J. Oxycodone
default: The most likely contributor to your constipation is the hydrocodone-acetaminophen you have been taking. Opioids, including hydrocodone, are known to cause constipation by slowing down bowel motility. Additionally, the iron supplement (ferrous sulfate) can also contribute to constipation in some individuals. It's important to discuss this with your healthcare provider, as they may suggest dietary changes, increased fluid intake, or a laxative to help manage this side effect.

question:
During my routine primary care visit, I underwent a urinalysis, which revealed 3+ protein and 1–2 red blood cells per high-power field. I did not experience any symptoms and have no relevant family history. Additionally, I do not smoke or consume alcohol. 

My vital signs were taken, showing a temperature of 36.7°C (98.06°F), blood pressure of 130/82 mm Hg, and a pulse rate of 78 beats per minute. The physical examination did not reveal any abnormalities. 

Given the findings, I was informed that further steps were necessary to manage my condition. The healthcare provider discussed the options available for further evaluation, considering the presence of protein and red blood cells in my urine. It was determined that additional tests would be needed to understand the significance of these results and to guide any potential treatment.
options: A. Repeating the urine dipstick test B. 24-hour urine collection C. Referring to a nephrologist immediately D. Ordering a renal biopsy E. Performing a kidney ultrasound F. Prescribing a low-protein diet G. Testing for urinary Bence Jones proteins H. Starting captopril I. Measuring serum albumin and creatinine J. Initiating corticosteroid therapy
default:
The presence of 3+ protein and 1–2 red blood cells per high-power field in your urinalysis suggests possible kidney involvement or other underlying conditions. Given that you are asymptomatic and have no significant risk factors, the next steps typically include:

1. **Repeat Urinalysis**: To confirm the findings and rule out transient causes.
2. **Urine Protein-to-Creatinine Ratio**: To quantify proteinuria more accurately.
3. **Blood Tests**: Including kidney function tests (e.g., serum creatinine) and possibly a complete metabolic panel.
4. **Imaging Studies**: Such as an ultrasound of the kidneys, if indicated.

These evaluations will help determine the underlying cause of the proteinuria and hem

question:
I am a 33-year-old male construction worker. Recently, I was found unconscious at my worksite and was brought to the emergency department. Prior to this incident, I had a medical history that included a seizure disorder and schizophrenia, for which I take haloperidol. Additionally, I had undergone an appendectomy two months ago.

Upon arrival at the hospital, I was experiencing acute confusion and was non-communicative. My clothing was soaked with sweat, and my vital signs indicated a high temperature of 105°F, a heart rate of 150 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 120/84 mmHg. My respiratory rate was 19 breaths per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 99% while breathing room air. 

During the examination, although there were no clear focal neurological deficits, I was unable to show purposeful movement in my extremities. The medical team assessed my condition and considered various possible diagnoses based on my symptoms and medical history.
options: A. Anticholinergic toxicity B. Exertional heat stroke C. Malignant hyperthermia D. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome E. Central nervous system infection F. Drug-induced hyperthermia G. Septic shock H. Nonexertional heat stroke I. Thyroid storm J. Status epilepticus
default: Based on the provided information, the most likely diagnosis is neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). This condition can occur in patients taking antipsychotic medications like haloperidol, especially when there is a recent change in dosage or non-compliance. The symptoms of high fever, autonomic instability (elevated heart rate), altered mental status, and muscle rigidity align with NMS. Immediate medical intervention is necessary, including discontinuation of the antipsychotic and supportive care.

question:
I was admitted to the emergency department in a comatose state, having experienced active rectal bleeding. I have no known medical history that could explain this condition. Upon arrival, my vital signs were taken: my pulse was 110 beats per minute, blood pressure measured at 90/60 mm Hg, my respiratory rate was 26 breaths per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 96% while breathing room air. My extremities felt cold to the touch.

After initial resuscitation efforts involving intravenous fluids and a blood transfusion, my vital signs stabilized. A nasogastric tube was inserted, revealing bile-stained fluid, but no blood. A rectal examination and proctoscopy were performed, which indicated significant active bleeding at an estimated rate of 2-3 mL per minute, though no hemorrhoids or fissures were found.

Given the circumstances and findings, the next diagnostic step needed to determine the source of the bleeding was under consideration. Various options were evaluated based on the situation at hand.
options: A. Repeat nasogastric lavage B. Exploratory laparotomy with segmental bowel resection C. Colonoscopy D. Push enteroscopy E. Capsule endoscopy F. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) G. CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis H. Mesenteric angiography I. Upper endoscopy J. Tagged red blood cell scintigraphy
default: In this scenario, given the active rectal bleeding and the findings from the nasogastric tube and proctoscopy, the next appropriate diagnostic step would be to perform a **colonoscopy**. This procedure allows for direct visualization of the colon and can help identify potential sources of bleeding, such as diverticula, tumors, or vascular malformations, which may not have been evident during the proctoscopy.

question:
I am a 55-year-old male who recently visited my primary care physician due to worsening pain in my left knee that I have been experiencing for the past year. I noticed that using ice and resting my knee provided only minor relief. Recently, I bumped my knee, but this incident did not change my baseline pain when walking. I work as a butcher and live with my wife, and my current medications include insulin, metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, and lisinopril. I have been attending Alcoholics Anonymous, although I have had limited success with it.

During my visit, my vital signs were taken, showing a temperature of 98.7°F, blood pressure at 137/88 mmHg, a pulse of 65 beats per minute, and respirations at 11 per minute. My oxygen saturation was measured at 98% while breathing room air. The physical examination of my left knee revealed mild redness and bruising, but there was no tenderness or pain when my knee was moved passively. I demonstrated a slightly antalgic gait, indicating an attempt to avoid pain while walking. The doctor discussed potential management options for my knee condition.
options: A. MRI B. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection C. Knee replacement evaluation D. Glucosamine supplementation E. Physical therapy referral F. Colchicine G. Joint immobilization H. Arthroscopic debridement I. Weight loss J. Aspirin
default:
Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it seems you may be experiencing knee osteoarthritis or possibly a mild knee injury, given the history of pain and the recent bump. The mild redness and bruising could indicate some inflammation, but the absence of tenderness during passive movement is a positive sign.

Management options may include:

1. **Physical Therapy**: To strengthen the muscles around the knee and improve mobility.
2. **Activity Modification**: Adjusting your work activities to reduce strain on the knee.
3. **Pain Management**: Over-the-counter NSAIDs (if appropriate for your health conditions) or topical analgesics.
4. **Weight Management**: If applicable, as reducing weight can alleviate stress on the knee.
5. **Injections

question:
I am a 45-year-old man who recently sought medical attention for back pain that started about two weeks ago. This pain coincided with an increase in my computer work due to a major project deadline. I do not have any significant medical history or recent trauma that could explain this discomfort.

During the examination, the healthcare provider conducted an osteopathic structural assessment. They noted that my paraspinal muscles in the lower cervical and upper thoracic regions were hypertonic and mildly tender. Specifically, I experienced sharp tenderness on the right side, just medial to the medial border of my scapula, particularly during anterior motion testing.

When I performed forward flexion, the left transverse process at that level seemed to move posteriorly more than expected. Based on these observations, the examiner considered various potential diagnoses related to my condition.
options: A. T4 NRRSR B. T5 NSLSL C. T2–T6 NSLRR D. T5 ERRSL E. T6 FRLSR F. T5 NRRSL G. T6 ERLSL H. T4 FRLSL I. T5 FRRSR J. T6 FRRSL
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it appears you may be experiencing a musculoskeletal issue related to postural strain, likely due to increased computer work. The hypertonicity and tenderness in the paraspinal muscles, along with the sharp tenderness near the scapula and the abnormal movement of the left transverse process during forward flexion, suggest a possible diagnosis of a cervical or thoracic strain, potentially with associated muscle tension or a mild facet joint dysfunction. It would be advisable to consider physical therapy for posture correction, stretching, and strengthening exercises, along with ergonomic adjustments to your workspace.

question:
I am a 19-year-old female athlete seeking sports clearance evaluation. At the time of the assessment, I was asymptomatic, but I have a history of multiple spontaneous pneumothoraces. During the physical examination, the physician noted several findings. It was observed that I have joint hypermobility and a chest wall deformity, specifically pectus excavatum, which is a depression of the sternum. Additionally, the examination revealed a decreased upper-to-lower body segment ratio.

Given my medical history and the findings from the examination, the physician considered what additional clinical findings might be present. Among the possibilities were conditions such as pes planus (flat feet), mitral valve prolapse, arachnodactyly (long, slender fingers), kyphosis, a midsystolic ejection murmur, increased arm span-to-height ratio, thoracolumbar scoliosis, hyperopia, aortic root dilation, and lens dislocation (ectopia lentis). The evaluation aimed to ensure that I was fit for sports participation while taking into account my unique medical history and physical characteristics.
options: A. Pes planus (flat feet) B. Mitral valve prolapse C. Arachnodactyly (long, slender fingers) D. Kyphosis E. A midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the right second intercostal space F. Increased arm span-to-height ratio G. Thoracolumbar scoliosis H. Hyperopia I. Aortic root dilation J. Lens dislocation (ectopia lentis)
default:
Given your history of multiple spontaneous pneumothoraces, joint hypermobility, pectus excavatum, and decreased upper-to-lower body segment ratio, the physician may be considering the possibility of a connective tissue disorder, such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. 

Key clinical findings that could be relevant include arachnodactyly, aortic root dilation, and lens dislocation, which are associated with Marfan syndrome. Additionally, joint hypermobility and pectus excavatum can be seen in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. The physician will likely assess for these conditions to ensure your safety in sports participation, particularly given the risk of cardiovascular complications and potential for further pneumothoraces.

question:
I am a 52-year-old woman who recently attended a follow-up visit to manage my menopausal hot flashes. My medical history includes hypertension, dyslipidemia, osteoporosis, and hypothyroidism due to Hashimoto's disease. Three months ago, I started a treatment regimen that includes oral estradiol and micronized progesterone for my hot flashes, omeprazole for dyspepsia, and calcium for my osteoporosis. Since then, I have noticed improvements in both my hot flashes and mood.

During the visit, I reported experiencing dry skin, occasional constipation, and mild fatigue. However, I denied any dyspepsia, depressed mood, hair loss, or weight changes. I have not had any falls or fractures recently. My current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, alendronate, cholecalciferol, and levothyroxine.

The physical examination conducted was unremarkable. I am aware that my thyroid function tests have shown some changes over the past six months, but I did not discuss the specific laboratory results during this visit. I am focused on managing my symptoms and continuing my current treatment plan.
options: A. Initiation of estradiol B. Impact of changes in body weight C. Interference from concurrent progesterone therapy D. Seasonal variation in thyroid function E. Drug interaction with atorvastatin F. Interaction between alendronate and levothyroxine G. Inadequate levothyroxine dose adjustment H. Interference of levothyroxine absorption by calcium supplementation I. Progression of underlying Hashimoto's thyroiditis J. Drug interaction with omeprazole
default: It sounds like you're making progress in managing your menopausal symptoms with the current treatment regimen. However, given your history of hypothyroidism and the mention of changes in your thyroid function tests, it would be important to review those results to ensure your levothyroxine dosage is appropriate. The dry skin, occasional constipation, and mild fatigue could be related to thyroid function, so monitoring and possibly adjusting your thyroid medication might be necessary. Continue to communicate any new symptoms or concerns with your healthcare provider to optimize your treatment plan.

question:
I was diagnosed with hairy-cell leukemia after a six-month delay. Initially, my blood work revealed pancytopenia, but the follow-up was not pursued. This oversight prompted a root cause analysis to understand the factors that led to my delayed diagnosis. 

During the investigation, participants were interviewed, and the process was reviewed to identify both proximate causes and contributing factors. The analysis aimed to establish a clearer understanding of what went wrong and how similar situations could be prevented in the future. 

At this stage of the investigation, the appropriate next steps were considered. Options included focusing on individual accountability for the missed follow-up, creating a flowchart to illustrate the sequence of key events, or developing an action plan that assigns responsibilities to mitigate future errors. Other possibilities included evaluating the current information technology for laboratory management, conducting a failure mode and effects analysis to assess potential risks, or performing a time-motion study to identify inefficiencies in result reporting workflows. 

There was also the option to convene a multidisciplinary team to review the laboratory reporting process, perform a retrospective chart review of similar cases, address any gaps in the electronic medical record system, or implement a system for automatic alerts for abnormal lab results. Each of these actions could play a crucial role in improving the diagnostic process.
options: A. Focus on individual accountability of the physician who missed follow-up B. Create a flowchart to illustrate the sequence of key events in this case C. Create an action plan to assign responsibilities to prevent similar errors in the future D. Evaluate the current information technology for laboratory management E. Conduct a failure mode and effects analysis to evaluate potential risks in the system F. Perform a time-motion study to identify inefficiencies in result reporting workflows G. Convene a multidisciplinary team to review the laboratory reporting process H. Perform a retrospective chart review of other cases with similar errors I. Identify and address gaps in the electronic medical record system J. Implement a system for automatic alerts for abnormal lab results
solution_text: Create an action plan to assign responsibilities to prevent similar errors in the future
default: The next appropriate step in your investigation should be to convene a multidisciplinary team to review the laboratory reporting process. This approach allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the entire workflow, encourages collaboration among different specialties, and can lead to actionable insights that address systemic issues.
