options: A. Low serum cortisol B. XY karyotype C. Growth hormone deficiency D. Elevated FSH levels E. Low serum aldosterone F. Hypokalemia G. Primary hypothyroidism H. Hyperandrogenism I. Turner syndrome karyotype J. Aromatase enzyme deficiency
default: Your situation suggests a possible hormonal imbalance or a condition affecting your development, such as hypogonadism or a genetic disorder. The elevated blood pressure could also be a concern. Further evaluations, including hormone level tests (like estrogen and testosterone), imaging studies (like an ultrasound), and possibly genetic testing, may be necessary to determine the underlying cause of your delayed puberty. It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider for a comprehensive assessment and to discuss your concerns.

question:
I arrived at the emergency department feeling intense lower abdominal pain, which had suddenly started while I was walking home after playing football. The pain was also localized in my right groin, and I began feeling nauseous, leading to vomiting over the past three hours. 

I have no significant medical history and do not take any medications. Upon my arrival, the medical staff took my vital signs. My temperature was measured at 36°C (96.8°F), my blood pressure was 136/82 mm Hg, my heart rate was 87 beats per minute, and my respiratory rate was 17 breaths per minute.

During the physical examination, the doctor noted that my abdomen was soft and non-tender. However, there was swelling on the right side of my scrotum, and I experienced persistent tenderness when they elevated my testicle. They also observed that the cremasteric reflex was absent on the right side.

Given these findings, further evaluation was likely to reveal a significant issue related to blood flow to my right testicle.
options: A. decreased arterial blood flow to the right testicle B. increased muscle tension in the paravertebral tissue at T10-T11 C. warm, rubbery tissue at the level of T11-L2 D. tenderness localized to the pubic symphysis E. inflammation and erythema of the epididymis F. gangliform nodule between the transverse and spinous processes of L1 G. referred pain to the lower extremity due to sciatic nerve compression H. impaired lymphatic drainage of the inguinal region I. hypertonicity of the pelvic floor muscles J. diminished cremasteric reflex bilaterally
solution_text: increased muscle tension in the paravertebral tissue at T10-T11
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it is highly suggestive of testicular torsion. The sudden onset of severe lower abdominal and groin pain, nausea, vomiting, scrotal swelling, tenderness upon testicle elevation, and the absence of the cremasteric reflex are classic signs. Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency that requires prompt intervention to restore blood flow and prevent testicular necrosis. Immediate evaluation with an ultrasound to assess blood flow to the testicle is critical.
alternative: increased muscle tension in the paravertebral tissue at T10-T11

question:
I am a 24-year-old male parkour athlete, and I began experiencing mid-back pain four days ago. The pain prompted me to seek medical attention. During the examination, I was assessed neurologically, and the results were normal. 

The structural examination revealed that the right transverse process of the affected vertebra appeared more posterior compared to the left. Interestingly, this asymmetry resolved when I bent forward. The spinous process of the affected vertebra aligned with the T10 transverse process level. 

Given these findings, the healthcare provider discussed various potential diagnoses related to the observed spinal alignment and movement.
options: A. T9 extended, rotated left, sidebent right B. T10 extended, rotated right, sidebent right C. T9 neutral, rotated right, sidebent right D. T9 extended, rotated right, sidebent right E. T8 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right F. T11 flexed, rotated left, sidebent left G. T10 flexed, rotated right, sidebent left H. T10 flexed, rotated left, sidebent right I. T9 flexed, rotated left, sidebent left J. T9 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right
solution_text: T9 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right
default: Based on your description, the findings suggest a possible diagnosis of a vertebral dysfunction, such as a segmental dysfunction or a mild scoliosis. The posterior positioning of the right transverse process and the alignment of the spinous process with the T10 transverse process indicate a potential rotational or positional issue in the thoracic spine. The resolution of asymmetry upon forward bending may suggest a muscular or postural component contributing to the pain. It's important to follow up with a physical therapist or chiropractor for targeted treatment and rehabilitation to address the underlying issues.
alternative: T9 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right

question:
I am a 43-year-old man who visited the emergency department after noticing bright red blood in my stool this morning. I had also seen smaller amounts of blood yesterday. The night before, I had celebrated my birthday and drank excessively, which led to heavy vomiting overnight. At the time of my visit, I felt well and did not experience any nausea.

My medical history is unremarkable, and I am not currently taking any medications. When my vital signs were taken, my temperature was 99.2°F, blood pressure was 110/75 mmHg, my pulse was 82 beats per minute, and my respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute. My oxygen saturation was 100% while breathing room air.

During the physical examination, my abdomen was nontender with normal bowel sounds. However, the rectal examination revealed grossly bloody stool. The medical team conducted several laboratory tests to assess my condition. 

At this point, I am seeking to understand the most likely cause of my symptoms, given the circumstances surrounding my recent celebration and subsequent gastrointestinal issues.
options: A. Mallory-Weiss tear B. Inflammation and infection of colonic outpouching C. Ischemic colitis D. Colonic angiodysplasia E. Submucosal esophageal tear F. Rectal fissure G. Vascular malformation H. Erosion into a gastric vessel I. Hemorrhoidal bleeding J. Peptic ulcer disease
default: Given your recent history of heavy drinking and vomiting, the most likely cause of the bright red blood in your stool is a tear in the rectal mucosa, commonly known as a rectal fissure, or possibly hemorrhoids exacerbated by straining during vomiting. The blood is likely from the lower gastrointestinal tract, especially since you felt well and had no other significant symptoms. However, it’s important to rule out other potential causes, such as diverticular disease or gastrointestinal bleeding from other sources, through further evaluation.

question:
I am a 25-year-old woman who visited my primary care physician due to pain during urination that started about three days ago. I noticed that I needed to urinate more frequently, but I did not observe any blood in my urine. I did not have any fevers, chills, vaginal discharge, or pain in my abdomen or flank. I also confirmed that I had not recently taken any antibiotics or been hospitalized.

My medical history is unremarkable, and I am not currently taking any medications. I have been in a monogamous relationship for the past four years and use a copper intrauterine device for contraception.

During my appointment, the physician noted that my temperature was 99°F, my blood pressure was 125/75 mmHg, my pulse was 72 beats per minute, and my respirations were 16 per minute. Upon examination, there was mild tenderness when my suprapubic area was palpated, but there was no tenderness in the costovertebral angle.

The physician discussed the next steps in my management.
options: A. Fosfomycin B. Ciprofloxacin C. Cephalexin D. Levofloxacin E. Doxycycline F. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole G. Azithromycin H. Observation with follow-up in 2 weeks I. Amoxicillin-clavulanate J. Ampicillin
default:
Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it is likely that you have a urinary tract infection (UTI). The pain during urination, increased frequency, and mild suprapubic tenderness support this diagnosis, even in the absence of blood in the urine or systemic symptoms like fever.

The next steps in your management would typically include:

1. **Urinalysis**: To check for signs of infection, such as white blood cells, nitrites, or bacteria.
2. **Urine Culture**: If the urinalysis suggests a UTI, a culture may be performed to identify the specific bacteria and determine the appropriate antibiotic treatment.
3. **Antibiotic Therapy**: If a UTI is confirmed, you would likely be prescribed a

question:
I am a 22-year-old woman who recently gave birth vaginally after a labor induction that lasted over 30 hours with continuous oxytocin infusion. My pregnancy had been uncomplicated, and I had been using albuterol for my asthma. 

Immediately following the delivery, I experienced ongoing vaginal bleeding. The placenta was delivered intact, but I lost more than 1050 mL of blood. Despite aggressive management efforts, including uterine massage and intramuscular oxytocin, along with continuous oxytocin infusion, my uterus remained boggy. 

A medical examination showed that there were no cervical lacerations or clots in the lower uterine segment, which indicated that the source of the bleeding was not from those areas. The healthcare team was faced with deciding on the most appropriate next intervention to address my condition.
options: A. Perform manual exploration of uterus B. Administer methylergonovine intramuscularly C. Initiate crystalloid fluid resuscitation D. Initiate tranexamic acid infusion E. Provide an additional dose of oxytocin intravenously F. Begin misoprostol administration G. Administer carboprost intramuscularly H. Perform immediate hysterectomy I. Insert Bakri balloon J. Begin fresh frozen plasma transfusion
default: Given the scenario of ongoing vaginal bleeding and a boggy uterus despite uterine massage and oxytocin administration, the most appropriate next intervention would be to perform a uterine curettage (D&C) to assess for retained products of conception, which could be contributing to the uterine atony and bleeding. If retained tissue is found, it can be removed, which may help stabilize the uterus and reduce bleeding. Additionally, if the bleeding persists, further interventions such as uterine artery embolization or surgical options like a hysterectomy may need to be considered based on the clinical situation.

question:
I am a 44-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection that did not respond to previous treatments, including peginterferon, ribavirin, and telaprevir. I also have a history of alcohol use disorder but have maintained sobriety for the past three years. I do not use tobacco or recreational drugs.

During my recent follow-up visit, the physical examination revealed scattered spider telangiectasias on my anterior chest wall. My abdomen was nontender, and the liver edge was not palpable. However, the tip of my spleen was palpable 1 cm below the costal margin when I was positioned on my right side.

I had several laboratory tests done. My HCV genotype was identified as 1a, and my HCV RNA level was 1,500,000 IU/mL. The international normalized ratio was 1.3, and I tested negative for hepatitis A, hepatitis B, and HIV. My alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase levels were elevated, while my albumin level was slightly low. My hemoglobin and platelet counts were also below the normal range.

Given my medical history and the examination findings, I am now considering the most appropriate screening tests for my condition.
options: A. CT scan of the abdomen and serum alpha-fetoprotein B. Liver biopsy and serum alpha-fetoprotein C. MRI of the liver and serum alpha-fetoprotein D. Abdominal ultrasound and liver function tests E. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and measurement of serum alpha-fetoprotein F. CT scan of the abdomen and esophagogastroduodenoscopy G. Measurement of serum alpha-fetoprotein H. Abdominal ultrasound and liver elastography I. MRI of the liver and liver biopsy J. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and abdominal ultrasound
default:
Given your history of chronic hepatitis C infection, elevated liver enzymes, splenomegaly, and cytopenias (low hemoglobin and platelet counts), the most appropriate screening tests to consider would be:

1. **Liver Ultrasound**: To assess for liver cirrhosis and any focal lesions or nodules.
2. **Transient Elastography (FibroScan)**: To evaluate liver stiffness, which can indicate fibrosis or cirrhosis.
3. **Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) Screening**: Given your risk factors, including chronic HCV and cirrhosis, regular screening with ultrasound (and possibly alpha-fetoprotein levels) is recommended.

These tests will help assess the extent

question:
I am a 23-year-old woman and recently visited my primary care provider due to experiencing a burning sensation behind my sternum and difficulty swallowing, known as odynophagia. My medical history includes hypothyroidism, endometriosis, nodulocystic acne, and chronic fatigue syndrome. 

I take several medications, including a combined oral contraceptive, levothyroxine, doxycycline, and naproxen, typically before bedtime because I often forget to take them in the morning. I have not been exposed to any illnesses recently.

During my visit, my vital signs were measured, and my temperature was 98.9°F. My blood pressure was recorded at 120/80 mmHg, with a heart rate of 70 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. My body mass index (BMI) was noted as 21.5 kg/m². The physical examination included lung auscultation, which revealed clear sounds bilaterally, and the examination of my abdomen showed no tenderness or guarding.

Based on my symptoms and examination, an upper endoscopy has been scheduled to further investigate my condition. I am aware that the procedure may reveal various findings, but I am particularly curious about what might be observed during the endoscopy.
options: A. Salmon-colored mucosa under white light in distal esophagus B. Mirror-image ulcers surrounded by normal mucosa in mid-esophagus C. Scattered punched-out ulcers throughout the entire esophagus D. Diffuse erythema with punctate hemorrhages in distal esophagus E. Circumferential erosions with adherent white exudates F. Whitish plaques with underlying erythematous mucosa G. Longitudinal streaks with friable mucosa and contact bleeding H. Cobblestone appearance with multiple superficial erosions I. Linear furrows with stacked circular rings and white papules J. Serpiginous ulcers with raised borders in proximal esophagus
solution_text: Mirror-image ulcers surrounded by normal mucosa in mid-esophagus
default:
During the upper endoscopy, several potential findings could be observed that may explain your symptoms of burning sensation behind the sternum and odynophagia. These may include:

1. **Esophagitis**: Inflammation of the esophagus, possibly due to acid reflux or irritation from medications.
2. **Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)**: Evidence of reflux, such as erosions or strictures.
3. **Hiatal Hernia**: A condition where part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm, which can contribute to reflux symptoms.
4. **Esophageal Strictures**: Narrowing of the esophagus that can cause difficulty swallowing.
5. **Barrett's Esophagus**: A precancerous
alternative: Mirror-image ulcers surrounded by normal mucosa in mid-esophagus

question:
I am a 28-year-old male who started experiencing pain in my left knee about two months after I sprained my ankle while playing basketball. The knee pain worsens when I fully extend my leg, and I have not found relief from ibuprofen or icing the area. I have a history of multiple ankle sprains but have never had knee pain before this incident.

During a physical examination, the doctor noted tenderness on the lateral side of my left knee and observed limited anterior movement of the left fibular head. Interestingly, my left ankle showed no signs of pain or swelling. After taking X-rays of my left lower extremity, the results indicated there were no fractures present.

Given my symptoms and examination findings, the doctor is considering what additional issues might be present related to my condition.
options: A. Plantarflexion of the foot B. Pain with resisted eversion of the foot C. Increased external rotation of the tibia D. Restricted anterior glide of the talus E. Tenderness over the medial collateral ligament F. Dorsiflexion of the foot G. External rotation of the talus H. Increased valgus stress of the knee I. Hyperextension of the knee J. Decreased internal rotation of the tibia
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it is possible that you may be experiencing a lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury or a meniscal tear, particularly given the tenderness on the lateral side of your knee and the limited movement of the fibular head. The history of ankle sprains could also suggest a compensatory mechanism that may have affected your knee alignment or stability. Further imaging, such as an MRI, may be warranted to assess for soft tissue injuries, including ligamentous or meniscal damage. Additionally, a thorough evaluation of your biomechanics and any potential underlying issues related to your previous ankle injuries could provide further insight into your knee pain.

question:
I am a 65-year-old man with a 50 pack-year smoking history, and I have been diagnosed with stage IV non-small-cell lung cancer that has spread to my lungs, bones, and liver. Recently, I was enrolled in a clinical trial at an academic medical center where I was randomized to receive a PD-1 inhibitor as a first-line treatment.

During the trial, I underwent several radiologic assessments at different intervals. At baseline, my right lung lesion measured 4.0 x 3.0 cm, and by week 16, it measured 3.6 x 2.6 cm. The left lung lesion started at 3.0 x 1.5 cm and increased to 2.6 x 1.5 cm by week 16. My liver lesion was 5.0 x 2.0 cm at baseline and later decreased to 2.5 x 1.2 cm.

Given these measurements, I began to analyze my response status at week 16. I noticed that while some lesions showed a decrease in size, others had an increase, indicating a mixed response to the treatment. This experience has been both challenging and enlightening as I navigate through my treatment options.
options: A. Delayed progression B. Disease flare C. Initial response followed by progression D. Pseudoprogression E. Complete response F. Mixed response G. Partial response H. Progressive disease I. Stable disease J. Treatment failure
default: Based on the radiologic assessments at week 16, you are experiencing a mixed response to the PD-1 inhibitor treatment. The right lung lesion has decreased in size, indicating a positive response, while the left lung lesion has increased slightly, suggesting progression. The liver lesion has also shown a significant decrease, which is another positive indicator. In mixed response scenarios, it's important to discuss with your oncologist the implications for your treatment plan, as some lesions responding positively can still be beneficial even if others are not. Your ongoing evaluation and adjustments to treatment will be crucial in managing your condition.

question:
I am a 72-year-old male who began experiencing a cough and pleuritic chest pain about two months ago. During this time, I noticed a weight loss of 5 kg (11 lb) over the past month, along with intermittent swelling in my face and arms, which seemed to worsen when I lay flat. Recently, I have also had some visual disturbances. 

I have a history of smoking for 50 years but quit last year, and I consume alcohol occasionally. During a physical examination, the doctor noted that I had right-sided ptosis and miosis, as well as distended veins in my neck, chest, and arms. When they listened to my lungs, they reported clear breath sounds on both sides. 

Given these symptoms and findings, imaging was performed to investigate further. The healthcare team is currently trying to determine the location of a mass based on the results of a CT scan.
options: A. Brain stem metastasis B. Cervical lymph nodes C. Anterior mediastinum D. Right upper lobe E. Right lower lobe F. Left lower lobe G. Pleural cavity H. Posterior mediastinum I. Central hilar region J. Left upper lobe
default: Based on the symptoms and findings you've described, it is highly suggestive of a Pancoast tumor, which is a type of lung cancer that occurs at the apex of the lung. The combination of your cough, pleuritic chest pain, weight loss, facial and arm swelling (indicative of superior vena cava syndrome), right-sided ptosis and miosis (Horner's syndrome), and visual disturbances points towards a malignancy affecting the surrounding structures, including the sympathetic chain and possibly the brachial plexus. The distended veins in your neck and upper extremities further support the diagnosis of superior vena cava obstruction, commonly associated with Pancoast tumors. The imaging results will be crucial in confirming the presence and extent of the mass.

question:
I am a 28-year-old woman who has not given birth. I experienced amenorrhea for two months after stopping my oral contraceptive pills, which I had been taking since I was 24. I began my menstrual cycles at age 13 and generally had regular 28-30 day cycles prior to starting contraception. Two months ago, I decided to stop taking the pills in hopes of conceiving.

During this time, I took multiple home pregnancy tests, all of which returned negative results. I do not have any history of sexually transmitted infections, nor have I experienced vaginal bleeding, discharge, spotting, or symptoms such as hot flashes. 

At my recent physical examination, my BMI was measured at 26, with a height of 165 cm and weight of 72 kg. I also noted some facial acne but did not exhibit signs of acanthosis nigricans, skin tags, galactorrhea, or hirsutism. The rest of the examination was unremarkable, and an in-office urine pregnancy test also confirmed that I am not pregnant.

Given my situation, I am now considering the most appropriate next step in evaluating my condition.
options: A. Begin clomiphene citrate therapy B. Measure her serum human chorionic gonadotropin level C. Measure serum testosterone and DHEA-S levels D. Perform transvaginal ultrasound to evaluate ovarian structure E. Perform endometrial biopsy F. Order pelvic MRI to evaluate hypothalamic-pituitary anatomy G. Order thyroid function tests and prolactin level H. Measure her follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels I. Continue to monitor her for one more month J. Start progesterone challenge test
solution_text: Continue to monitor her for one more month
default: Given your history of amenorrhea after stopping oral contraceptives and the negative pregnancy tests, the most appropriate next step in evaluating your condition would be to conduct hormonal testing. This typically includes measuring levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), estradiol, and possibly thyroid function tests (TSH) and prolactin levels. These tests can help assess ovarian function and rule out conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or thyroid disorders that could be contributing to your amenorrhea.
alternative: Continue to monitor her for one more month

question:
I am a 28-year-old woman who recently visited my physician due to ongoing issues with low energy and irritability that have persisted for several weeks. I had been excited after being accepted into a master’s program, but once the semester started, I began to feel a sense of worthlessness. 

In reflecting on my experiences, I noticed that I often undergo mood swings. There are periods where I feel highly productive and in an elevated mood, followed by phases of fatigue, guilt, and depressive symptoms that last for several weeks. I do not currently take any medications and typically consume 2-3 glasses of wine on weekends. 

During my physical examination, the findings were normal. However, during the mental status examination, I appeared tired and had difficulty maintaining attention, requiring some questions to be repeated for clarity. Given these symptoms and experiences, I am seeking to understand what might be the most likely diagnosis for my condition.
options: A. Premenstrual dysphoric disorder B. Persistent depressive disorder C. Cyclothymic disorder D. Generalized anxiety disorder E. Bipolar II disorder F. Borderline personality disorder G. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood H. Bipolar I disorder I. Substance-induced mood disorder J. Major depressive disorder
default: Based on your symptoms of mood swings, periods of elevated mood followed by fatigue and depressive symptoms, along with feelings of worthlessness and difficulty maintaining attention, it is possible that you may be experiencing Bipolar II Disorder. This condition is characterized by episodes of hypomania (elevated mood) and major depressive episodes. It would be advisable to discuss your symptoms further with a mental health professional for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate treatment options.

question:
I am a 68-year-old woman who visited my primary care physician due to persistent lower back pain that has lasted for four months. The pain is not linked to any specific activities and has not improved with over-the-counter medications. It has been disruptive enough to affect my sleep at night. In addition to the back pain, I have noticed an increase in fatigue and unintentional weight loss.

During the appointment, my medical history was reviewed, which includes hypertension that is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. My vital signs were recorded: I had a temperature of 36.9°C, blood pressure of 142/85 mmHg, a pulse of 78 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. 

The physical examination showed that I appeared pale, and when my lumbar spine was palpated, there was tenderness, but no deformity was noted. Given my symptoms and the examination findings, my physician discussed the need for further diagnostic testing to determine the underlying cause of my condition.
options: A. Bone marrow biopsy B. MRI of the lumbar spine C. Alkaline phosphatase measurement D. Peripheral blood smear E. Serum protein electrophoresis F. PET scan of the whole body G. CT scan of the axial skeleton H. Serum free light chain assay I. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan J. 24-hour urinary protein measurement
default: Given your symptoms of persistent lower back pain, fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and pallor, it is important to consider potential serious underlying conditions. The combination of these symptoms raises concern for possible malignancy, infection, or other systemic issues. Your physician will likely recommend imaging studies, such as an X-ray or MRI of the lumbar spine, and possibly blood tests, including a complete blood count (CBC) to check for anemia, inflammatory markers, and other relevant tests to assess for malignancy or infection. Prompt evaluation is crucial to determine the cause and initiate appropriate treatment.

question:
I am a 34-year-old woman of Indian descent, and I recently sought fertility consultation with my husband due to challenges we’ve faced in conceiving. We met during humanitarian work in Nepal about ten years ago. Over the past few months, I have experienced chronic, vague discomfort in my lower abdomen, along with irregular menstrual cycles that include spotting and the passage of blood clots.

I have not noticed any pain during intercourse, post-coital bleeding, or any unusual vaginal discharge. Additionally, I have not experienced fever or weight loss. During my physical examination, the doctor noted mild cervical bleeding and slight tenderness during the bimanual examination, but no palpable masses were found.

To further investigate, a hysterosalpingogram was performed, which indicated sinus tract formation and peritubal adhesions. As part of the evaluation, a sample of my menstrual fluid was sent for microbiological analysis to identify any potential pathogens that might be contributing to my symptoms. I am awaiting the results to better understand the underlying issues affecting my fertility.
options: A. *Mycoplasma genitalium* B. *Klebsiella granulomatis* C. *Treponema pallidum* D. *Chlamydia trachomatis* E. *Escherichia coli* F. *Ureaplasma urealyticum* G. *Actinomyces israelii* H. *Trichomonas vaginalis* I. *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* J. *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*
default:
Based on your symptoms and the findings from the hysterosalpingogram, it appears you may be experiencing issues related to pelvic adhesions and possibly endometriosis or another underlying condition affecting your reproductive health. The chronic discomfort, irregular cycles, and cervical bleeding suggest that there may be an inflammatory or infectious process at play, which the microbiological analysis will help clarify.

It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider to discuss the results of the microbiological analysis and any further diagnostic steps, such as a laparoscopy, which can provide a clearer picture of your pelvic anatomy and help address any adhesions or endometriosis. Early intervention can be crucial in improving fertility outcomes.

question:
I am a 25-year-old male who underwent a three-column excisional hemorrhoidectomy to address combined internal and external hemorrhoids that had not improved with medical treatment. The surgery was performed successfully, and I was in the postoperative recovery unit. However, on the evening following the procedure, I began to experience suprapubic pain accompanied by urinary retention.

The discomfort was notable, and I found it difficult to urinate. This situation prompted me to consider what might have contributed to these post-operative complications. Several factors were on my mind, including the possibility of local inflammation affecting the urethra, the limitations on intravenous fluids during my recovery, and the potential for nerve injury in the pelvic area. I also thought about the excessive pain I was experiencing, which could have led to urethral spasm, or whether the effects of spinal anesthesia were still lingering. Additionally, I wondered if post-operative edema might be compressing the urethra.

Overall, I recognized that multiple factors could have played a role in my condition, and I hoped to discuss these concerns with my healthcare provider for further clarification and resolution.
options: A. Local inflammation affecting urethral compliance B. Limiting intravenous fluids in the postoperative recovery unit C. Injury to pelvic nerves D. Excessive post-operative pain causing urethral spasm E. Residual effects of spinal anesthesia F. Post-operative edema compressing the urethra G. Inadequate post-operative pain management H. Inadequate perioperative fluid management I. Performing 3 quadrant hemorrhoidectomy instead of 2 J. Reactive bladder sphincter dysfunction
default: Your postoperative suprapubic pain and urinary retention could be attributed to several interrelated factors. Local inflammation from the surgery may have affected the surrounding tissues, potentially leading to urethral irritation or spasm. Additionally, the effects of spinal anesthesia can sometimes linger, impacting bladder function and sensation. Pain management is crucial, as excessive pain can also contribute to urinary retention. Lastly, postoperative edema in the pelvic area might compress the urethra, further complicating urination. It's important to discuss these concerns with your healthcare provider for appropriate evaluation and management.

question:
I was brought to the emergency department by my mother after experiencing 12 hours of lethargy and poor feeding. We live in a small rural town in the Appalachian mountains, and no one else in my family is showing similar symptoms. Recently, I have been teething, and my mother has been using a teething ring to help me through it. I am breastfed, but I am in the process of being weaned onto infant formula and baby food.

I have no significant medical history, am not on any medications, and my immunizations are current. My growth parameters are at the 50th percentile for both length and weight. Upon arrival, my vital signs were taken: I had a temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F), a pulse of 120 beats per minute, and my respirations were at 38 per minute. However, my oxygen saturation was only 86% on room air.

During the physical examination, I appeared quite sleepy, and my skin, lips, and tongue displayed cyanosis. The doctor listened to my chest, and it seemed unremarkable. After some evaluations, it was determined that something was contributing to my condition, possibly related to how my body was handling oxygen.
options: A. Abnormal hemoglobin polymerization under physiologic oxygen levels B. Low partial pressure of oxygen in ambient air C. Decreased activity of a reducing enzyme in erythrocytes D. Increased levels of methemoglobin in the blood E. Inhalation of an odorless gas with high hemoglobin affinity F. Impaired oxygen diffusion across alveolar membranes G. Ingestion of a toxin that inhibits mitochondrial respiration H. Cyanotic congenital heart defect I. Increased production of fetal hemoglobin J. Defective oxygen unloading due to abnormal hemoglobin structure
solution_text: Decreased activity of a reducing enzyme in erythrocytes
default:
Based on the symptoms and findings described, it is likely that you are experiencing a case of acute respiratory distress, possibly due to a viral infection or another underlying condition affecting your oxygenation. The lethargy, poor feeding, cyanosis, and low oxygen saturation suggest that your body is struggling to get enough oxygen, which could be related to a respiratory issue, such as bronchiolitis or pneumonia, especially given your age and recent teething.

The fact that you are being weaned onto formula and baby food may also indicate a change in your diet that could contribute to dehydration or nutritional deficiencies, but the acute nature of your symptoms points more towards a respiratory cause. Immediate evaluation and treatment in the emergency department are crucial to address your oxygen levels and
alternative: Decreased activity of a reducing enzyme in erythrocytes

question:
I was brought to the emergency department due to experiencing respiratory distress. My aunt and uncle, who were caring for me for the weekend, noticed that I had mild coughing and congestion the day before, but I seemed fine until I woke up crying and struggling to breathe. They mentioned that my voice sounded unusual, but they were unsure about my vaccination status. I have no known prior health issues, and a test for SARS-CoV-2 came back negative.

When I entered the room, the medical staff observed that I had inspiratory stridor and a barking cough. I was in moderate respiratory distress, but I did not appear toxic. I had nasal congestion and exhibited moderate subcostal and intercostal retractions. The chest examination revealed symmetric air entry without wheezes or rales. I was well-hydrated, and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.

My temperature was recorded at 38.5°C, my respiratory rate was 38 breaths per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. The medical team then assessed my condition and considered the most appropriate next step for my management.
options: A. Administer nebulized albuterol and prednisolone B. Transfer to pediatric intensive care unit C. Order chest CT scan D. Administer dexamethasone E. Perform nasopharyngeal endoscopy F. Obtain anteroposterior and lateral neck radiographs G. Begin empiric antibiotic therapy H. Initiate nebulized epinephrine treatment I. Order immediate blood cultures J. Administer supplemental oxygen
solution_text: Obtain anteroposterior and lateral neck radiographs
default:
Based on the symptoms described—specifically the inspiratory stridor, barking cough, moderate respiratory distress, and fever—the clinical picture is suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), which is common in young children and often caused by viral infections, particularly parainfluenza virus.

The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer a dose of dexamethasone to reduce inflammation in the airway. If the stridor is significant or the respiratory distress worsens, nebulized epinephrine may also be considered for immediate relief. However, the initial focus should be on corticosteroid administration.
alternative: Obtain anteroposterior and lateral neck radiographs

question:
I am a 51-year-old male with a history of hypertension. For the past six months, I have been experiencing intermittent fevers, worsening shortness of breath, orthopnea, fatigue, and chest pain. 

During my recent medical examination, the healthcare provider noted that my jugular venous pressure was normal. However, they detected faint bilateral crackles in both of my lung fields. Additionally, during cardiac auscultation, an early diastolic sound followed by a soft, mid-diastolic murmur was heard at the apex of my heart. The examination did not reveal any conjunctival or skin abnormalities. 

Given my symptoms and the findings from the physical examination, my healthcare provider is considering various potential diagnoses. I am awaiting further evaluation to determine the underlying cause of my condition.
options: A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy B. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis C. Subacute bacterial endocarditis D. Mitral valve infective endocarditis E. Constrictive pericarditis F. Mitral valve prolapse G. Cardiac myxoma H. Atrial septal defect I. Acute viral myocarditis J. Rheumatic mitral stenosis
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, particularly the intermittent fevers, worsening shortness of breath, orthopnea, fatigue, chest pain, and the presence of an early diastolic sound followed by a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex, a likely diagnosis to consider is mitral stenosis. The faint bilateral crackles in the lung fields suggest pulmonary congestion, which can occur with heart valve abnormalities. Further evaluation, including echocardiography, will be essential to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of any valvular heart disease.

question:
I am a 15-year-old girl who has a history of obesity, with a BMI consistently above the 95th percentile since infancy. Recently, I became concerned about excessive hair growth on my face, abdomen, and lower back. I started my menstrual cycles at age 12, but over the past year, they have been irregular. 

During my examination, the doctor noted that I had moderate hirsutism and thickened, hyperpigmented skin on the back of my neck. To further understand my condition, several laboratory tests were conducted. The results indicated a mildly elevated total testosterone level, while my prolactin, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, follicle-stimulating hormone, estradiol, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and first-morning 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels were normal. Additionally, a urine test for human chorionic gonadotropin came back negative.

Given my symptoms and the results of the examination and tests, my doctor is considering the most appropriate screening test for my situation.
options: A. Glucagon stimulation test B. Hemoglobin A1C measurement C. C-peptide measurement D. Measurement of fasting plasma glucose E. Insulin tolerance test F. Post-prandial glucose measurement G. Random blood glucose test H. 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test I. Measurement of C peptide with random plasma glucose J. Fasting insulin level
default: Based on your symptoms of hirsutism, irregular menstrual cycles, obesity, and the mildly elevated total testosterone level, your doctor is likely considering screening for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The most appropriate screening test in this context would be a transvaginal ultrasound to assess for the presence of ovarian cysts, which is a common finding in PCOS. Additionally, your doctor may also consider measuring insulin levels or conducting an oral glucose tolerance test to evaluate for insulin resistance, which is often associated with PCOS.

question:
I am a 46-year-old Thai immigrant and recently presented to the hospital due to persistent, sharp abdominal pain that had lasted for 28 hours. Along with the abdominal pain, I experienced multiple episodes of vomiting. My medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia, which I manage with atorvastatin and gemfibrozil.

During my physical examination, the medical staff noted that I had a temperature of 38.6°C (101.5°F), a blood pressure of 119/72 mmHg, and a pulse of 83 beats per minute. They observed tenderness in my right upper quadrant and noted scleral icterus, dry mucosal membranes, and delayed capillary refill. However, my abdomen was not distended.

The medical team conducted laboratory tests to further assess my condition. While I do not have the specific results in front of me, they indicated an elevated leukocyte count and bilirubin levels. The doctors were considering potential pathogens that could be the cause of my symptoms. I was anxious about the situation but remained focused on understanding the underlying issue.
options: A. *Enterococcus faecalis* B. *Echinococcus granulosus* C. *Staphylococcus aureus* D. *Clonorchis sinensis* E. *Ascaris lumbricoides* F. *Opisthorchis viverrini* G. *Escherichia coli* H. Hepatitis C virus I. *Klebsiella pneumoniae* J. *Salmonella typhi*
default: Based on your symptoms and clinical findings, it appears you may be experiencing acute cholecystitis, likely due to gallstones, especially given the right upper quadrant tenderness, fever, and jaundice (scleral icterus). The elevated leukocyte count suggests an inflammatory process, and the elevated bilirubin levels could indicate a bile duct obstruction or liver involvement. Given your history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia, these factors could contribute to gallstone formation. It's important to follow up with imaging studies, such as an ultrasound, to confirm the diagnosis and guide further management.

question:
I am a 67-year-old male who recently visited my primary care physician due to concerns about difficulty achieving an erection. Since experiencing a heart attack a month ago, I have been unable to maintain an erection, despite finding my wife sexually attractive and wanting to engage in intercourse. This situation has made me feel guilty and I have noticed a change in my mood, feeling more depressed than usual. Additionally, I have observed a decrease in my energy levels and a reduced interest in my hobby of working on motorcycles.

During my appointment, my vital signs were taken; my blood pressure was 152/99 mmHg, my pulse was 87 beats per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. The physical examination revealed that I am obese, but my external genitalia appeared normal. My dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were graded at 1+, and my gait, strength, and sensation were all normal.

I have recently started taking medications following my heart attack, which I believe may be contributing to my symptoms. I am seeking to understand the most likely cause of my erectile difficulties and the associated feelings of guilt and depression.
options: A. Cardiovascular deconditioning B. Aortoiliac occlusion C. Depression D. Medication side effect E. Performance anxiety disorder F. Anxiety G. Peripheral vascular disease H. Psychogenic erectile dysfunction I. Testosterone deficiency J. Post-MI autonomic dysfunction
default:
Your erectile difficulties are likely multifactorial, primarily influenced by the recent heart attack, which can lead to both physical and psychological changes. The medications you started after your heart attack, particularly if they include beta-blockers or other antihypertensives, may also contribute to erectile dysfunction. 

Additionally, the feelings of guilt and depression you're experiencing are common in men facing sexual health issues, especially after a significant health event like a heart attack. The combination of physical health decline, medication side effects, and emotional stress can significantly impact libido and erectile function.

It's important to discuss these concerns with your physician, as they may consider adjusting your medications or referring you to a specialist for further evaluation and management of both your erectile dysfunction and mood changes. Addressing

question:
I am a 45-year-old male who recently visited my healthcare provider for a routine examination. I reported no current complaints and shared that I have successfully quit smoking. During the visit, my vital signs were stable, and the physical examination did not reveal any significant issues.

As part of the assessment, an osteopathic structural evaluation was conducted. During this evaluation, a pattern of decreased cranial rhythmic impulse was noted, which was consistent with findings from previous visits. The assessment indicated a cranial strain pattern characterized by a cephalad movement of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis occurring around two transverse axes.

This evaluation led to a discussion about the best diagnosis corresponding to these findings. I was informed that there are several potential diagnoses to consider, including options such as temporal bone external rotation and vertical strain dysfunction, among others.
options: A. Temporal bone external rotation B. Vertical strain dysfunction C. Persistent sacral nutation D. Occipitomastoid compression E. Sphenobasilar torsion F. Cranial flexion G. Sphenobasilar extension H. Cranial compression I. Atlanto-occipital joint dysfunction J. Lateral strain pattern
default: Based on the findings of decreased cranial rhythmic impulse and the specific cranial strain pattern described, the most likely diagnosis is a **vertical strain dysfunction**. This is characterized by the cephalad movement of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis around the transverse axes, which aligns with the cranial mechanics observed during your evaluation.

question:
I am a 32-year-old woman who has been experiencing abdominal pain, which I would describe as a mild "tummy ache." This discomfort has persisted for about a week. Over the past month, I have found it challenging to engage in my daily activities. I often feel sad and lack motivation, which has made it difficult for me to concentrate on my work. Some days, I struggle to get out of bed, and I’ve noticed that I am sleeping for 10 to 12 hours, which I attribute to a heavy sensation in my legs. 

Additionally, I have observed an increase in my appetite recently. These symptoms have significantly affected my overall well-being and day-to-day functioning. I am trying to understand the impact of these feelings and behaviors on my life, and I am seeking to identify any additional features related to my condition.
options: A. Feelings of grandiosity and decreased need for sleep B. An increased frequency of symptoms during winter C. Avoiding social activities due to fear of rejection D. Persistent thoughts about maintaining cleanliness E. Intrusive thoughts about past traumatic events F. Periods of intense anger followed by remorse G. Excessive worry about multiple life circumstances H. Guilt related to the way she treats others I. Difficulty maintaining relationships due to unstable self-image J. Recurrent episodes of panic with autonomic symptoms
solution_text: Avoiding social activities due to fear of rejection
default:
It sounds like you're experiencing a combination of physical and emotional symptoms that could be indicative of a few underlying issues. The persistent abdominal pain, fatigue, changes in sleep patterns, increased appetite, and feelings of sadness and lack of motivation may suggest a possible mood disorder, such as depression, which can manifest with physical symptoms. 

It's important to consider that emotional distress can often lead to physical symptoms, and vice versa. The heaviness in your legs and the difficulty in engaging in daily activities could also be related to anxiety or stress. 

Given the duration and impact of your symptoms, I recommend seeking professional help from a healthcare provider. They can conduct a thorough evaluation to determine the underlying causes and suggest appropriate treatment options, which may include therapy, lifestyle changes,
alternative: Avoiding social activities due to fear of rejection

question:
I am a 14-year-old boy who recently joined a new medical practice. During my visit, I had no current health complaints to report. However, my parents informed the doctor about a significant family history of intestinal polyps on my father’s side. I mentioned that I had not noticed any blood in my stool.

The doctor conducted a thorough examination. My vital signs were measured, and my heart rate was 80 beats per minute, with a blood pressure of 110/68 mm Hg. My respiratory rate was recorded at 16 breaths per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 98% while breathing room air. The doctor noted that my sclerae were clear, without any yellowing, and I had freckles around my mouth. 

During the abdominal examination, my abdomen felt soft and was nontender and nondistended. A rectal examination showed no fissures, tags, or hemorrhoids, which was reassuring. 

Despite the absence of immediate health issues, I am aware of the potential risks associated with my family history, particularly concerning intestinal polyps, as I approach the age of 18.
options: A. Malignant melanoma B. Intussusception C. Small bowel obstruction D. Gastrointestinal bleeding E. Bowel infarction F. Mesenteric ischemia G. Intestinal perforation H. Longitudinal melanonychia I. Colonic volvulus J. Colon cancer
default: Given your family history of intestinal polyps, it's important to stay vigilant about your health as you approach adulthood. While your current examination shows no immediate concerns, you should discuss with your doctor the appropriate screening measures, such as a colonoscopy, especially as you near 18. Regular monitoring and open communication with your healthcare provider will help manage any potential risks associated with your family history.

question:
I am a 45-year-old male exterminator. About a week ago, I began experiencing persistent headaches and a nonproductive cough. Alongside these symptoms, I noticed some redness and irritation in my eyes, which I later recognized as conjunctival suffusion. 

Upon reflection, I recalled that I had sustained a rat bite eight days prior to the onset of my symptoms. This incident has made me consider the possibility of a bacterial infection related to the bite. Given the timeline and my symptoms, I am concerned about the potential health implications. 

I have not yet sought medical attention but feel it is important to address these symptoms as they continue to affect my daily activities. I understand that specific bacterial infections could be linked to rodent exposure, and I am now looking into the most likely causes based on my recent experiences.
options: A. Francisella tularensis B. Bartonella henselae C. Rickettsia typhi D. Spirillum minus E. Leptospirosis F. Borrelia recurrentis G. Streptobacillus moniliformis H. Capnocytophaga canimorsus I. Pasteurella multocida J. Yersinia pestis
default: Based on your symptoms and recent rat bite, you may be at risk for leptospirosis or hantavirus, both of which can be associated with rodent exposure. Leptospirosis can cause headaches, cough, and conjunctival suffusion, while hantavirus can lead to respiratory symptoms and other systemic issues. Given the potential severity of these infections, it is crucial that you seek medical attention promptly for evaluation, diagnosis, and appropriate treatment.

question:
I am a 40-year-old male who have been experiencing a 5-month history of watery diarrhea, which is often accompanied by episodic crampy abdominal pain. Over the past six months, I have lost about 1.8 kilograms in weight, despite maintaining a normal appetite. My wife has observed that I experience facial and neck flushing after meals or during times of distress.

In terms of my medical history, I was diagnosed with asthma a year ago and also have hypertension. I am currently using an albuterol inhaler and taking enalapril for my blood pressure. Additionally, I consume one beer daily.

During my recent examination, my temperature was recorded at 36.7°C, my pulse was 85 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was 130/85 mm Hg. The doctor noted a grade 2/6 systolic murmur during the cardiac examination, and my abdomen was mildly tender, but there was no guarding or rebound tenderness. My lungs were clear upon auscultation. A complete blood count was performed, and the results were normal.

I am aware that if my condition is left untreated, there are several potential risks, and I am concerned about what complications could arise from my symptoms.
options: A. Malabsorption syndrome B. T-cell lymphoma C. Achlorhydria D. Metastatic liver disease E. Right-sided heart failure F. Dementia G. Carcinoid heart disease H. Bronchial carcinoid I. Megaloblastic anemia J. Cushing syndrome
default:
Based on your symptoms of watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and facial flushing, you may be experiencing a condition such as a neuroendocrine tumor (e.g., VIPoma) or another gastrointestinal disorder like carcinoid syndrome. The flushing and diarrhea, particularly after meals, suggest a possible hormonal imbalance affecting your gastrointestinal function.

If left untreated, potential complications could include:

1. **Dehydration and Electrolyte Imbalance**: Chronic diarrhea can lead to significant fluid loss, resulting in dehydration and imbalances in electrolytes, which can be life-threatening.

2. **Nutritional Deficiencies**: Ongoing diarrhea can impair nutrient absorption, leading to deficiencies in vitamins and minerals, which can affect overall health.

question:
I was admitted to the emergency room due to facial pain, weakness, and a general feeling of malaise. On top of that, I was experiencing a throbbing headache. I have a medical history that includes type II diabetes and HIV infection. Although I take several medications, including zidovudine, lamivudine, lopinavir, ritonavir, and metformin, I have not been very compliant with them lately.

During the examination, the doctor noted that there was exquisite tenderness when my right maxillary sinus was palpated. They also observed a black eschar present over my nares and palate. Given my symptoms and medical history, the healthcare team was concerned about the possibility of severe complications related to my condition.

I was informed that certain symptoms could indicate a more serious issue, such as impaired extraocular eye movements, unilateral ptosis, retro-orbital pain, proptosis with chemosis, reduced ability to detect odors, blood-tinged nasal discharge, diplopia with lateral gaze, decreased corneal reflex, altered mental status, or facial numbness in the V2 distribution. These potential complications were explained to me as part of their assessment and management plan.
options: A. Impaired extraocular eye movements B. Unilateral ptosis C. Retro-orbital pain D. Proptosis with chemosis E. Reduced ability to detect odors F. Blood-tinged nasal discharge G. Diplopia with lateral gaze H. Decreased corneal reflex I. Altered mental status J. Facial numbness in V2 distribution
default: Based on your symptoms, medical history, and the presence of a black eschar, there is a strong concern for mucormycosis, particularly given your immunocompromised state due to HIV and potential non-compliance with medications. The exquisite tenderness in the right maxillary sinus and the systemic symptoms you described further support this diagnosis. Mucormycosis can lead to serious complications, including orbital involvement and central nervous system effects, which align with the symptoms you were informed about. Immediate intervention, including antifungal treatment and possibly surgical debridement, is critical to manage this condition effectively. Please follow up closely with your healthcare team for appropriate management.

question:
I am an 80-year-old woman living alone, and I recently visited urgent care due to worsening fatigue I had been experiencing over the past two days. I found myself needing more daytime naps and felt persistently tired, even after what I thought was restful sleep at night. Typically, I can carry two bags of groceries from my car to my kitchen without much trouble, but yesterday I struggled to carry even one bag and needed to rest after each trip.

I did not have any chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, chills, or any issues with urination or respiratory symptoms like cough or congestion. I did note that my teenage grandson had visited last week and had a runny nose and cough, but I did not think much of it at the time.

During my examination, the healthcare provider noted that I appeared fatigued but was not in acute distress. They performed several tests, including vital signs and a cardiopulmonary examination, all of which came back normal. I also learned that I am up to date on my vaccinations for Covid-19, influenza, and pneumonia.

Now, I am left wondering what the most appropriate next step in managing my condition should be.
options: A. Refer to physical therapy B. Initiate a trial of corticosteroids for possible inflammatory condition C. Refer for a sleep study to evaluate for obstructive sleep apnea D. Order a thyroid-stimulating hormone level E. Prescribe empiric antibiotics for possible bacterial infection F. Check serum ferritin and iron studies for possible anemia G. Order a brain MRI to rule out a central nervous system etiology H. Order a chest CT to rule out occult pulmonary pathology I. Order a viral respiratory panel including SARS-CoV-2 J. Perform an echocardiogram to evaluate for heart failure
solution_text: Order a viral respiratory panel including SARS-CoV-2
default: Given your symptoms of worsening fatigue, increased need for naps, and difficulty with daily activities, it's important to follow up with your primary care physician. They can conduct a more comprehensive evaluation, including blood tests to check for anemia, thyroid function, or other underlying conditions that could contribute to your fatigue. Additionally, they may assess your overall health and consider any recent changes in your lifestyle or medications. It's also advisable to monitor your symptoms closely and seek immediate care if you experience any new or worsening symptoms.
alternative: Order a viral respiratory panel including SARS-CoV-2

question:
I am a 73-year-old male who has been experiencing worsening pain in both of my lower extremities for the past eight months. This pain typically begins after walking one to two blocks and radiates down to my buttocks, often accompanied by cramping and tingling sensations. I have noticed that the pain worsens when I walk downhill, but it eases when I sit down or lean forward.

My medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a myocardial infarction at age 55. I also underwent an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair at age 60. I have a long history of smoking, having smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years, but I do not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. 

Currently, I take several medications, including sitagliptin, metformin, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate, amlodipine, and hydrochlorothiazide. During my recent examination, my vital signs showed a temperature of 37.5°C, a pulse of 82 beats per minute, respirations at 17 per minute, and blood pressure recorded at 150/87 mm Hg. The physical examination indicated full muscle strength, but I had reduced sensation in my feet and toes bilaterally. The straight leg raise test came back negative, and an X-ray of my spine revealed degenerative changes. 

I am now considering the most appropriate next diagnostic step to address my symptoms.
options: A. CT angiography of lower extremities B. Bone scan C. Nerve conduction studies D. EMG of lower extremities E. Measurement of the ankle brachial index F. CT scan of the spine G. Measurement of HLA-B27 antigen H. Doppler ultrasound of lower extremities I. MRI scan of the spine J. Plain radiographs of the lumbar spine with flexion and extension views
default: Given your symptoms of bilateral lower extremity pain, cramping, and tingling that worsen with walking and improve with sitting, along with your history of vascular issues and degenerative changes in the spine, the most appropriate next diagnostic step would be to obtain an MRI of the lumbar spine. This imaging can help assess for potential spinal stenosis or other structural issues that may be contributing to your symptoms.

question:
I am a 24-year-old male who arrived at the emergency department after my car was hit from behind while it was stationary. The other vehicle was traveling at a low speed of 11 miles per hour. Following the collision, I experienced intense back pain but did not report any other symptoms. 

I have a history of back pain for which I have been undergoing physical therapy. My back pain tends to be most severe in the mornings, improves with physical activity, and worsens when I am inactive. As a university student, I have been facing academic difficulties, which adds to my stress.

Upon evaluation in the emergency department, my vital signs were stable, and I was found to have spinal tenderness and a limited range of motion during the physical examination, which was primarily restricted due to pain. I was seeking documentation to excuse me from my final examinations and work duties, as the pain was affecting my ability to function normally.
options: A. Herniated nucleus pulposus B. Psychogenic pain disorder C. Acute disc herniation D. Musculoskeletal strain E. Spondylolisthesis F. Factitious disorder G. Conversion disorder H. Malingering I. Spinal cord contusion J. Vertebral fracture
default:
Based on your description, it seems you are experiencing an exacerbation of your chronic back pain following the low-speed collision. Given your history of back pain, the spinal tenderness, and limited range of motion, it is important to manage your pain effectively and consider a treatment plan that may include rest, physical therapy, and possibly pain management strategies.

For documentation to excuse you from examinations and work duties, it would be advisable to have a healthcare provider formally assess your condition. They can provide a note that outlines your current symptoms, the impact on your daily functioning, and recommendations for rest or modified activities. This documentation will help support your request for accommodations during this time.

question:
I am a 44-year-old female and have been experiencing progressive scleral icterus and itching for the past three months. I do not have any significant medical history and I am not currently taking any medications. When I visited the doctor, my vital signs were normal, but during the physical examination, the doctor noted that my sclerae were icteric and there were linear scratch marks on my trunk and extremities. Other findings from the examination were unremarkable. 

Despite the physical examination, the doctor decided to conduct further tests. The results showed that my hemoglobin, leukocyte count, and liver enzymes were within certain ranges, and my total bilirubin was elevated. An MRCP was performed, which demonstrated diffuse beading of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with multifocal involvement. 

Given these findings, there was a discussion about the next appropriate diagnostic test. The options included various procedures such as colonoscopy, nuclear medicine hepatobiliary scan, and others, but the best course of action was still under consideration.
options: A. Colonoscopy B. Nuclear medicine hepatobiliary scan C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) D. Upper endoscopy (EGD) E. Liver biopsy F. No further testing is indicated G. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) H. Antimitochondrial antibody testing I. Serum IgG4 level testing J. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
default:
Based on the symptoms and test results you've described, particularly the progressive scleral icterus, itching, elevated total bilirubin, and the MRCP findings of diffuse beading of the bile ducts, the clinical picture is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). 

In this context, the next appropriate diagnostic test would be a colonoscopy with biopsy to evaluate for associated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), particularly ulcerative colitis, which is commonly associated with PSC. This would help confirm the diagnosis and guide further management.

question:
I am a 77-year-old man who recently visited the clinic with my daughter for a routine follow-up appointment. I did not have any complaints during the visit, but my daughter mentioned that I had been feeling more fatigued during exertion and had been sleeping more often. Just last week, I completed a 10-day course of ciprofloxacin for a prostate infection, and my urinary symptoms have resolved completely.

My medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and moderate vascular dementia. I take several medications daily, including donepezil, verapamil, lisinopril, sotalol, and apixaban.

During the physical examination, my temperature was measured at 37.2°C, my blood pressure was 130/60 mm Hg, and my heart rate was noted to be 45 beats per minute. My respiratory rate was recorded at 12 breaths per minute, and my lungs were clear upon examination. The doctor observed a regular heart rhythm with no murmurs, but I did have mild pitting edema in both lower legs.

After our discussion, the doctor considered the next steps for my care, weighing options based on my current health status and symptoms.
options: A. Reduce the sotalol dose by 50% B. Obtain an electrocardiogram C. Check serum digoxin level D. Initiate temporary pacing E. Order an echocardiogram F. Schedule Holter monitoring G. Obtain cardiac biomarkers H. Check serum electrolytes I. Stop the verapamil with close follow-up J. Obtain thyroid function tests
default:
Given your symptoms of increased fatigue during exertion, bradycardia (heart rate of 45 bpm), and mild pitting edema, it’s important to consider the potential impact of your medications, particularly sotalol, which can cause bradycardia. The combination of your heart rate and fatigue may indicate that your heart is not pumping effectively, possibly due to the effects of your medications or underlying cardiac issues.

The doctor may consider adjusting your sotalol dosage or switching to a different antiarrhythmic medication. Additionally, monitoring your renal function and electrolytes is crucial, especially since you have diabetes and are on multiple medications. The mild edema could also suggest fluid retention, which may need further evaluation.

Overall, the next steps would

question:
I am a 47-year-old man who recently sought medical attention due to persistent fatigue and a noticeable decrease in libido. Over the past year, I've observed a decline in my sexual interest, experiencing infrequent morning erections and only mild erections during masturbation. Occasionally, I wake up with headaches in the morning.

I have two healthy children, aged 15 and 17, and I have been divorced. My puberty was normal, and I do not have any history of testicular trauma or mumps infection. I have not noticed any loss of axillary or pubic hair, and a physical examination confirmed that these hair patterns are normal. However, I learned that both of my testicles measure approximately 10 cc, which is below the reference range.

My body mass index (BMI) is 38, indicating obesity. During my visit, visual field testing returned normal results. I am now awaiting additional diagnostic tests to determine the underlying cause of my symptoms.
options: A. Karyotype analysis B. Sleep study C. Semen analysis D. Abdominal ultrasound E. Serum cortisol measurement F. MRI of the pituitary G. Bone density scan H. Genetic testing for Klinefelter syndrome I. Dynamic pituitary hormone testing J. Testicular ultrasound
default:
Your symptoms, including persistent fatigue, decreased libido, infrequent morning erections, and mild erections during masturbation, along with the finding of smaller testicle size, suggest a potential hormonal imbalance, possibly related to low testosterone levels. The obesity (BMI of 38) can also contribute to hormonal changes and may exacerbate these symptoms. 

The normal visual field testing is reassuring, as it helps rule out pituitary issues that could affect hormone levels. It's important to await the results of your additional diagnostic tests, which may include hormone panels (like testosterone, LH, FSH) and possibly imaging studies to assess the pituitary gland or other factors. Addressing lifestyle factors, such as weight management, can also be beneficial in improving your symptoms.

question:
I am a 45-year-old male who recently visited the clinic for an evaluation of my dyslipidemia. A week prior, I had a fasting lipid panel that indicated elevated triglycerides, although I am currently asymptomatic. My medical history includes an aortic valve replacement and type II diabetes mellitus. I take several medications, including aspirin, warfarin, regular insulin, and atorvastatin. 

During the visit, my vital signs were measured: my temperature was 37.0°C, pulse was 90 beats per minute, respirations were 17 per minute, and blood pressure was 125/80 mmHg. The physical examination showed no abnormalities. My healthcare provider informed me that my INR was 1.5, and my serum creatinine was 1.2 mg/dL. 

The provider discussed starting fenofibrate therapy to manage my triglyceride levels. I was informed that an intervention should be implemented before beginning this new medication. I understand the importance of monitoring my health closely, especially given my background and current treatment regimen.
options: A. Obtain baseline thyroid function tests B. Obtain gallbladder ultrasound C. Monitor blood glucose levels more frequently D. Obtain liver function test E. Increase aspirin dosage F. Decrease the warfarin dose G. Measure serum creatinine phosphokinase level H. Discontinue atorvastatin I. Check fasting lipid profile again J. Obtain renal function panel
default: Before starting fenofibrate therapy, it is essential to assess your renal function more closely, particularly because fenofibrate can increase the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis, especially in patients taking statins like atorvastatin. Given your serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL, your healthcare provider may want to ensure that your renal function is stable and consider adjusting your atorvastatin dosage if necessary. Additionally, monitoring your lipid levels and INR after starting fenofibrate will be important to ensure safety and efficacy.

question:
I am a 1-month-old male infant who was evaluated for feeding difficulties that have persisted for the past 10 days. During feeds, I experienced respiratory distress and sweating. I was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks, and there were no health issues noted before this evaluation. My birth measurements were 51 cm in length and 3660 g in weight. My initial Apgar scores were 8 and 9, and I was discharged from the hospital two days after birth since my examination was unremarkable.

During my current evaluation, it was noted that my growth is at the 20th percentile for length and the 10th percentile for weight. My vital signs included a temperature of 36°C, a heart rate of 190 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg. While my oxygen saturation in room air was 96%, I was found to be breathing laboriously. 

The physical examination revealed a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, but there was no cyanosis. An ECG indicated left-axis deviation, and a chest x-ray showed enlargement of the left atrium and ventricle with increased pulmonary vascularity. Doppler echocardiography confirmed the presence of an intracardiac shunt.
options: A. Closure of the ductus arteriosus B. Increase in systemic vascular resistance C. Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction D. Development of pulmonary venous congestion E. Increased left-to-right shunting due to septal defect enlargement F. Decreased systemic cardiac output G. Failure of physiologic cardiac remodeling H. Decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance I. Progressive right ventricular hypertrophy J. Persistent pulmonary hypertension
default: The clinical presentation and findings suggest that the infant is likely suffering from a congenital heart defect, specifically a ventricular septal defect (VSD) or possibly an atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD). The holosystolic murmur, respiratory distress during feeding, and signs of heart failure (e.g., tachycardia, poor weight gain) indicate increased pulmonary blood flow due to an intracardiac shunt. The left atrial and ventricular enlargement on chest x-ray further supports this diagnosis. Immediate evaluation and management by a pediatric cardiologist are warranted.

question:
I am a 32-year-old woman who recently experienced right-sided lower back pain. The discomfort began a few days ago, although I am not entirely sure when it started; I suspect it may have begun after waking up one morning. The pain is localized to my lower back and does not radiate to other areas.

I have a medical history that includes two pregnancies. I delivered my second child via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery about a year ago. At present, I do not have any additional symptoms accompanying the back pain.

During a recent examination, it was noted that my right sacral sulcus is shallow, and the right inferior lateral angle is positioned superiorly. There is tenderness in my lower lumbar paraspinal muscles on both sides, and a seated flexion test was positive on the left side. With these observations, I have been informed that there are several possible diagnoses to consider regarding my condition.
options: A. Bilateral sacral flexion about the middle transverse axis B. Left-on-left sacral torsion C. Right unilateral sacral flexion about the middle transverse axis D. Left unilateral sacral flexion about the superior transverse axis E. Right unilateral sacral extension about the superior transverse axis F. Left sacral rotation on a right oblique axis G. Right unilateral sacral flexion about the superior transverse axis H. Left unilateral sacral extension about the middle transverse axis I. Right-on-left sacral torsion J. Left unilateral sacral flexion about the middle transverse axis
solution_text: Left unilateral sacral flexion about the middle transverse axis
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it is possible that you are experiencing a musculoskeletal issue, such as a sacroiliac joint dysfunction or lumbar strain. The tenderness in the paraspinal muscles and the positive seated flexion test suggest a potential asymmetry or dysfunction in the pelvic or lumbar region. Given your recent pregnancy and delivery, changes in your body mechanics and muscle tone could also contribute to this pain. It would be advisable to follow up with a healthcare provider for a tailored treatment plan, which may include physical therapy, exercises, or other interventions to address the underlying issues.
alternative: Left unilateral sacral flexion about the middle transverse axis

question:
I am a 27-year-old woman with no significant medical history. Recently, I visited the clinic due to upper back pain that I have been experiencing, which seems to worsen when I study for extended periods. The pain is achy and is located in my upper back, rated at a 7 out of 10 in intensity. 

During my examination, the healthcare provider assessed my upper extremity strength and range of motion, both of which were normal on both sides. However, there was a localized area of tenderness identified on the left side of my back. This tenderness was specifically at the posterolateral aspect of the transverse process, just medial to the inferior angle of my scapula. 

The pain and its location led to a discussion about potential diagnoses, as the provider considered various options based on my symptoms and the physical examination findings. I left the appointment with a better understanding of my condition and next steps for management.
options: A. Serratus posterior superior strain B. Rhomboid major muscle spasm C. T7 posterior tender point D. Latissimus dorsi muscle strain E. Scapulothoracic bursitis F. T6 posterior tender point G. T12 posterior tender point H. T8 posterior tender point I. Myofascial pain syndrome involving the trapezius J. T9 posterior tender point
default:
Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it sounds like you may be experiencing a musculoskeletal issue, possibly related to muscle strain or myofascial pain syndrome, particularly given the localized tenderness near the transverse process and the exacerbation of pain with prolonged study. This type of pain is often associated with poor posture or prolonged static positions. 

Management typically includes physical therapy focusing on posture correction, stretching, and strengthening exercises, as well as pain relief strategies such as NSAIDs or heat therapy. If symptoms persist, further evaluation, such as imaging, may be warranted to rule out any underlying structural issues.

question:
I am a 39-year-old male with a history of heroin use disorder, for which I am currently receiving methadone treatment. Recently, I noticed a progressive swelling in my lower extremities that has persisted for the past two weeks. Alongside this, I have been experiencing fatigue and hematuria. I maintain a stable monogamous relationship and do not use any substances other than methadone.

During a physical examination, the doctor noted several findings, including conjunctival pallor, scleral icterus, and hepatomegaly. I also had noticeable acrocyanosis and 2+ pitting edema in my lower legs. My vital signs indicated mild hypertension, with a reading of 152/98 mmHg. 

The urinalysis showed proteinuria with dysmorphic red blood cells, and there were decreased levels of C3 and C4 complement in my blood tests. Given these symptoms and findings, I understand that there are various potential outcomes associated with renal biopsy results.
options: A. Membranoproliferative pattern with double contours B. Diffuse mesangial cell proliferation with capillary wall thickening C. Crescentic glomerulonephritis with fibrinoid necrosis D. Granular subepithelial immune deposits ("spike and dome" appearance) E. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis with podocyte effacement F. Nodular mesangial expansion with Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions G. Linear IgG deposits along glomerular basement membrane H. Glomerular basement membrane thinning and splitting I. Apple-green birefringence on Congo red stain J. Wire loop lesions with hyaline thrombi
solution_text: Diffuse mesangial cell proliferation with capillary wall thickening
