question:
I am a 65-year-old male who recently visited a neurologist after being referred by my primary care physician. For the past six months, I have been experiencing progressive bilateral leg pain, which is notably more severe in my left leg. I would describe the pain as a "burning" sensation and rate it around 5 out of 10 at its worst. The discomfort tends to worsen when I walk downhill but improves when I engage in activities like riding a stationary bike.

My medical history includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a prior myocardial infarction. I also had a distal radius fracture from a fall last year. Currently, I take several medications, including aspirin, atorvastatin, metformin, glyburide, enalapril, and metoprolol. I have a significant smoking history of 30 pack-years and typically drink 2-3 glasses of wine with dinner.

During my examination, my temperature was noted at 99°F, my blood pressure was 145/85 mmHg, and my pulse was 91 beats per minute. I appeared well and was not in acute distress. A straight leg raise test came back negative, and a Valsalva maneuver did not exacerbate my pain. The neurologist discussed which diagnostic tests might be appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis.
options: A. Computed tomography of the lumbar spine B. Ankle-brachial index C. Computerized tomography myelography D. Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities E. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies F. Magnetic resonance imaging G. X-ray of the lumbosacral spine H. Serum inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR, CRP) I. Myelography J. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA)
default:
Based on your symptoms and medical history, the neurologist may suspect a condition such as lumbar spinal stenosis or peripheral artery disease (PAD). The burning leg pain that worsens with walking downhill and improves with cycling suggests possible neurogenic claudication, often associated with spinal stenosis. However, given your significant smoking history and risk factors, PAD should also be considered.

To confirm the diagnosis, the neurologist might recommend imaging studies such as an MRI of the lumbar spine to assess for spinal stenosis or a Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities to evaluate for PAD. These tests will help determine the underlying cause of your leg pain and guide appropriate treatment.

question:
I am a 28-year-old woman who went to the emergency department after experiencing pain in my left forearm for one day. The discomfort began after I had spent several hours typing at work. I did not experience any trauma or have any similar episodes in the past. My medical history is generally unremarkable.

During the physical examination, the healthcare provider noted that my left elbow exhibited medial deviation of the olecranon and adduction of the wrist. There was tenderness around the proximal forearm, but I did not have any swelling or redness. The range of motion in my elbow was normal. 

The healthcare team considered several potential diagnoses related to somatic dysfunctions. They were focused on identifying the most likely issue based on my symptoms and examination findings.
options: A. Abduction of the ulna B. Posterior translation of the ulna C. Anterior translation of the ulna D. Interosseous membrane dysfunction E. Supination of the radius F. Ulnar head subluxation G. Proximal radioulnar joint dysfunction H. Adduction of the ulna I. Distal radioulnar joint dysfunction J. Pronation of the radius
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is a condition related to repetitive strain or overuse, such as medial epicondylitis (golfer's elbow) or a form of ulnar nerve entrapment. The medial deviation of the olecranon and wrist adduction suggest possible issues with the ulnar nerve or surrounding structures due to prolonged typing. It's important to consider ergonomic factors at your workstation and possibly implement rest, physical therapy, or other interventions to address the discomfort.

question:
I recently visited a behavioral health clinic after experiencing unusual visions for over two weeks. I began seeing clouds that took on the shapes of dogs, cats, and monkeys. My medical history includes simple partial seizures, for which I have been taking valproate at a consistent dosage for several years.

During my evaluation, my vital signs were recorded: my blood pressure was 124/76 mm Hg, my heart rate was 98 beats per minute, my respiratory rate was 12 breaths per minute, and my temperature was 37.1°C (98.8°F). I was alert and oriented throughout the examination, although my speech was rapid and loud. There were no abnormalities in my affect, and my pupils were equal and reactive.

A urine drug screen was conducted, which revealed the presence of alcohol and cocaine, while other substances were negative. This combination of factors prompted the healthcare team to consider the most likely explanation for my symptoms.
options: A. Delusion B. Psychotic episode C. Drug-induced psychosis D. Postictal confusion with perceptual distortion E. Hallucination secondary to seizure activity F. Illusion G. Perceptual disturbance due to alcohol use H. Cocaine intoxication I. Visual hallucination J. Misinterpretation of external stimuli
default: Your symptoms of unusual visions, rapid and loud speech, and the presence of alcohol and cocaine in your urine drug screen suggest a possible substance-induced psychotic disorder. The combination of these substances can lead to visual hallucinations and altered mental status. Additionally, your history of simple partial seizures and the use of valproate may complicate the clinical picture, but the acute onset of hallucinations in the context of substance use is the most likely explanation for your symptoms.

question:
I am a 45-year-old woman living with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Recently, I experienced a 3-week period marked by nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion, which prompted me to seek medical attention. My medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux disease, for which I have been using over-the-counter calcium carbonate antacids. I do not smoke or consume alcohol, and the only medication I take is metformin.

During my visit to the physician, my pulse was measured at 86 beats per minute, and my blood pressure recorded at 142/85 mm Hg. The examination revealed that my abdomen was soft. The physician conducted an arterial blood gas analysis while I was on room air. 

An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed, revealing a corrected QT interval of 0.36 seconds. The physician discussed my symptoms and the results further, considering various substances that could be elevated in my condition. This comprehensive evaluation aimed to identify the underlying causes of my symptoms and guide appropriate treatment.
options: A. 24,25-Dihydroxycholecalciferol B. Fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) C. Calcitonin D. Parathyroid hormone E. Alkaline phosphatase F. 1,25-Dihydroxycholecalciferol G. Calcium H. Phosphate I. Vitamin D-binding protein J. Magnesium
default:
Based on your symptoms of nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion, along with your medical history and the results of your examination, it is important to consider the possibility of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) or other metabolic disturbances, especially given your type 2 diabetes. 

The arterial blood gas analysis would help assess your acid-base status, and the ECG findings, particularly the corrected QT interval, suggest that there may be electrolyte imbalances, possibly related to your diabetes management or gastrointestinal issues. 

Elevated substances to consider include blood glucose levels, ketones, and possibly electrolytes like potassium, which can be affected by both diabetes and gastrointestinal symptoms. It would be crucial to follow up on these tests to determine the exact cause of your symptoms and to

question: When I was two weeks old, my parents brought me in for a routine evaluation. During this visit, the healthcare team informed them that my newborn screening for hemoglobinopathies indicated the presence of only hemoglobin F. The medical staff discussed the next steps in managing my condition. They considered various options, including obtaining a peripheral blood smear, scheduling a follow-up in three months, referring me to a pediatric hematologist, providing reassurance to my parents, performing a hemoglobin solubility test, repeating hemoglobin electrophoresis at six months, conducting family genetic screening, ordering globin gene testing, ordering a complete blood count with reticulocytes, and starting prophylactic iron supplementation. After weighing these options, the medical team decided on the most appropriate course of action to ensure my well-being and to address any potential concerns regarding my health moving forward.
options: A. Obtain a peripheral blood smear B. Schedule follow-up in 3 months C. Refer to pediatric hematologist D. Provide reassurance to the parents E. Perform hemoglobin solubility test F. Repeat hemoglobin electrophoresis at 6 months G. Perform family genetic screening H. Order globin gene testing I. Order complete blood count with reticulocytes J. Start prophylactic iron supplementation
default: Given the presence of only hemoglobin F in a two-week-old infant, the most appropriate course of action would likely be to schedule a follow-up in three months and consider repeating hemoglobin electrophoresis at that time. This approach allows for monitoring the infant's hemoglobin development, as hemoglobin F is normal in newborns and typically decreases as they grow. Additionally, reassurance for the parents is important, while further testing can be guided by the follow-up results.

question:
I am a 68-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease. I presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had lasted for about two hours, accompanied by one episode of bloody diarrhea. Upon arrival, my vital signs were stable: my temperature was 37.5°C, blood pressure measured 145/90 mm Hg, my pulse was 78 beats per minute, and my respirations were 14 per minute. I was alert and oriented.

During the physical examination, the doctor noted mild generalized tenderness in my abdomen, but there were no signs of guarding or rebound tenderness. An abdominal X-ray was performed, which appeared normal, but a CT scan revealed colonic wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding at the splenic curvature. 

After being diagnosed, I was placed on bowel rest, received intravenous hydration, and was started on antibiotics. The medical team then discussed the most appropriate next step for further diagnostic evaluation.
options: A. Colonoscopy B. Exploratory laparotomy C. Serum lactate measurement D. Sigmoidoscopy E. Angiography F. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen G. Stool culture and sensitivity H. Inpatient observation I. CT angiography of the abdomen J. Measurement of inflammatory markers (e.g., CRP, ESR)
default: Given your presentation of severe abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and the CT findings of colonic wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding, the most appropriate next step for further diagnostic evaluation would be a colonoscopy. This procedure can help visualize the colon directly, assess for any lesions, and obtain biopsies if necessary to determine the underlying cause of the colonic inflammation, such as infection, ischemia, or inflammatory bowel disease.

question:
I am a 55-year-old female who recently sought evaluation due to a 3-month history of difficulty walking. Throughout my life, I have experienced recurrent sprains in my left ankle. My medical history includes hypertension, which I manage with lisinopril.

During my evaluation, my vital signs were taken, showing a blood pressure of 136/90 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 37.6°C (99.7°F). I was alert and oriented during the examination.

The healthcare provider conducted a cardiac auscultation and noted a grade 1/6 systolic murmur at the left sternal border. Additionally, my lungs were clear upon examination. The provider then assessed my left ankle, focusing on the distal fibula, and observed external rotation of the talus.

Based on these findings, the provider considered various possible diagnoses related to my symptoms and history.
options: A. Cuboid somatic dysfunction B. Medial tibial torsion C. Talus anterior somatic dysfunction D. Subtalar joint dysfunction E. Distal fibular fracture without displacement F. Posterior fibular head dysfunction G. Navicular somatic dysfunction H. Lateral tibial torsion I. Anterior fibular head dysfunction J. Plantar fascia strain
default: Based on your symptoms and history, the most likely diagnosis is a chronic ankle instability, potentially due to recurrent sprains affecting the ligaments around the ankle joint. The external rotation of the talus suggests a possible issue with the stability of the ankle, which could be contributing to your difficulty walking. Additionally, the systolic murmur noted during cardiac auscultation is likely benign, given its low grade and the absence of other concerning findings. However, further evaluation, including imaging of the ankle, may be warranted to assess for any structural damage or ligamentous injury.

question:
I am a 52-year-old man with no significant prior medical history. For the past four months, I have been experiencing recurrent abdominal pain. Along with the pain, I have noticed that my stools have become foul-smelling and greasy. Despite my appetite remaining unchanged, I have lost 11 pounds during this period.

During a physical examination, the doctor found tenderness when palpating my right upper quadrant. To further investigate my condition, a fasting serum glucose test was conducted, and I learned that it was elevated at 186 mg/dL. An abdominal ultrasound was also performed, which showed multiple round, echogenic foci within my gallbladder lumen, accompanied by prominent posterior acoustic shadowing.

The combination of these symptoms and findings has raised concerns about my digestive health, and the medical team is considering which serum substances might be elevated in my case.
options: A. Cortisol B. Cholecystokinin C. Amylin D. Glucagon E. Insulin-like growth factor-1 F. Somatostatin G. Gastrin H. Pancreatic polypeptide I. Secretin J. Vasoactive intestinal peptide
default:
Based on your symptoms and findings, particularly the foul-smelling, greasy stools (indicative of malabsorption), right upper quadrant pain, and the ultrasound results showing echogenic foci in the gallbladder, it is likely that you have gallstones, possibly leading to cholecystitis or pancreatitis. 

In this context, the serum substances that might be elevated include:

1. **Amylase and Lipase**: If there is pancreatitis due to gallstone obstruction.
2. **Bilirubin**: If there is a bile duct obstruction.
3. **Alkaline Phosphatase**: If there is cholestasis or liver involvement.

Given your elevated fasting serum glucose, there may also be concerns

question:
I am a 31-year-old nurse who was brought to the emergency department by a colleague due to experiencing symptoms of weakness, shakiness, sweating, lightheadedness, and a pounding heartbeat. Upon arrival, I felt slightly confused, but I was still able to communicate. I informed the medical staff that I had experienced similar episodes three times in the past month. I do not have any chronic medical conditions and I am not currently taking any medications. 

My family history includes a notable mention of Grave's disease. During the examination, my vital signs were taken; my temperature was recorded at 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure at 132/94 mm Hg, respiratory rate at 24 breaths per minute, and pulse at 102 beats per minute. I appeared anxious and was sweating, but my pulse was regular, and there were no signs of peripheral edema or respiratory distress. 

The medical team decided to order toxicology and β-hCG tests to further assess my condition. I understood that additional diagnostic tests would likely be needed, but I was uncertain about which ones would be performed next.
options: A. Complete blood count (CBC) B. Electrocardiogram (ECG) C. Urine metanephrine D. Plasma metanephrines E. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) F. D-dimer test G. Fingerstick blood glucose H. Arterial blood gas (ABG) I. Serum cortisol level J. Serum insulin and C-peptide levels
default:
Based on your symptoms and history, the medical team is likely considering conditions such as hyperthyroidism, given your family history of Grave's disease, as well as potential hypoglycemia or anxiety-related disorders. The toxicology and β-hCG tests are appropriate initial steps to rule out substance use or pregnancy-related issues.

Next, they may perform additional tests such as:

1. **Thyroid function tests** (TSH, Free T4, Free T3) to assess for hyperthyroidism.
2. **Blood glucose level** to check for hypoglycemia.
3. **Complete blood count (CBC)** and **basic metabolic panel (BMP)** to evaluate overall health and electrolyte balance.

These tests will help clarify the underlying cause of your

question:
I am a 40-year-old male, and for the past two years, I have experienced progressively worsening shortness of breath. My history includes smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for about ten years, but I quit eight years ago. 

When I visited the doctor, my vital signs were recorded: a pulse of 72 beats per minute, blood pressure at 135/75 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. During the physical examination, the doctor noted an increased anteroposterior chest diameter and diminished breath sounds when listening to my lungs.

To further evaluate my condition, a chest x-ray was performed, which showed widened intercostal spaces, a flattened diaphragm, and bilateral basilar hyperlucency. Given my symptoms and medical history, I learned that I am at a high risk for a particular condition related to my lungs. 

Though the specific condition was not identified during the visit, the findings suggest I may need further evaluation to determine the underlying cause of my shortness of breath and the potential risks associated with my past smoking history.
options: A. Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax B. Hepatocellular carcinoma C. Pulmonary hypertension due to interstitial lung disease D. Bronchiolitis obliterans E. Cor pulmonale F. Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension G. Bronchogenic carcinoma H. Pulmonary fibrosis I. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy J. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency-related cirrhosis
default: Based on your symptoms, medical history, and the findings from your physical examination and chest X-ray, it is likely that you are experiencing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), specifically emphysema. The increased anteroposterior chest diameter, diminished breath sounds, and hyperlucency on the X-ray are indicative of this condition, which is commonly associated with a history of smoking. Further evaluation, such as pulmonary function tests, would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of your condition.

question:
I am a 6-year-old male who was brought to the emergency department after I grabbed a hairdryer while bathing, which exposed me to a low-voltage electrical current. After the incident, I experienced three episodes of vomiting. My mother also noticed that I was showing protective behavior with my right hand.

During the examination, the medical staff checked my vital signs, which included a heart rate of 95 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. My oxygen saturation was 98% while breathing room air. I felt disoriented and was intermittently moaning, but I opened my eyes when the staff spoke to me. 

The doctor examined my right hand, where they found a 3 cm erythematous and blistering lesion on my palm. They noted that I had intact sensation and strength in my hand, with no signs of severe injury like circumferential or white lesions. I withdrew in response to the placement of an IV and to being touched on my palm. My cardiopulmonary exam was normal, and my abdomen appeared unremarkable.

The ECG showed a normal sinus rhythm, and the medical team was considering the appropriate next steps in my management.
options: A. Serial troponin measurements B. Administration of IV antibiotics C. Consultation with a hand surgeon D. Tetanus prophylaxis administration E. Noncontrast CT of the brain F. Topical silver sulfadiazine application G. Immediate cardiac monitoring H. Immediate transfer to burn unit I. Emergent fasciotomy J. Pack the right hand in ice
default:
Given the scenario, the child is experiencing symptoms consistent with a low-voltage electrical injury, including disorientation, vomiting, and a blistering lesion on the palm. The intact sensation and strength in the hand, along with the normal cardiopulmonary exam and ECG, suggest that there are no immediate life-threatening complications.

The next steps in management should include:

1. **Observation and Monitoring**: Due to the disorientation and vomiting, the child should be closely monitored for any changes in neurological status or worsening symptoms.

2. **Fluid Management**: Administer IV fluids to prevent dehydration from vomiting.

3. **Pain Management**: Provide appropriate analgesia for the blistering lesion on the palm.

4. **Wound Care**: Assess

question:
I am a 29-year-old woman who regularly runs marathons. Recently, I started to experience an aching pain in my right groin after physical activity. Over time, this pain expanded to my pubic region, anterior hip, and lower abdomen, worsening particularly during running and when making directional changes.

During a physical examination, I noted tenderness over my pubic symphysis. I felt pain when pressure was applied to my right pubic ramus. Additionally, lying on my right side and actively adducting my right leg against resistance at the distal medial femur also caused discomfort.

Several tests were conducted, including hip flexion-adduction-internal rotation (FADIR), internal rotation of the extended leg while supine, resisted sit-up, and leg elevation. All these tests returned negative results.

Given my symptoms and the examination findings, I am seeking to understand the most probable diagnosis for my condition.
options: A. Trochanteric bursitis B. Athletic pubalgia C. Pelvic floor dysfunction D. Hip labral tear E. Osteitis pubis F. Femoral acetabular impingement G. Pubic ramus stress fracture H. Iliopsoas bursitis I. Sacroiliitis J. Adductor muscle strain
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, the most probable diagnosis is **pubic symphysis dysfunction** or **osteitis pubis**. The tenderness over the pubic symphysis, pain with adduction, and the location of your discomfort align with these conditions, which are common in athletes, especially runners. The negative results from the hip tests suggest that the hip joint itself may not be the primary issue, further supporting the diagnosis related to the pubic region. It would be advisable to consult a healthcare professional for a comprehensive evaluation and management plan.

question:
I am a 77-year-old man who recently sought medical evaluation due to a 10-day history of painful spasms in my right posterior thigh. My medical history includes hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and congestive heart failure. At the time of my visit, I was taking atorvastatin and furosemide for management of these conditions.

During the examination, my vital signs were stable, with a blood pressure of 136/78 mm Hg, heart rate of 76 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 37.4°C. I experienced mild discomfort, but my muscle strength was normal in both legs, rated at 5/5. 

The physician conducted a physical examination that included palpation of specific areas. They noted findings at the right-sided anterior superior iliac spine and the left-sided posterior superior iliac spine, as well as the right-sided ischial tuberosity. Additionally, a standing flexion test was positive on the right side. 

Given these observations, the physician assessed the potential causes of my symptoms, focusing on the possibility of somatic dysfunction related to various muscles in my right leg.
options: A. Right adductor magnus B. Right piriformis C. Right sartorius D. Right iliopsoas E. Right rectus femoris F. Right tensor fasciae latae G. Right gluteus medius H. Right gracilis I. Right vastus lateralis J. Right hamstring complex
default:
Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it appears that you may be experiencing somatic dysfunction, potentially related to muscle tightness or strain in the right posterior thigh. The positive standing flexion test on the right side suggests a possible asymmetry or restriction in the pelvis or lumbar spine, which could be contributing to your painful spasms. 

Given your age and medical history, including congestive heart failure, it's important to consider that muscle spasms can also be influenced by electrolyte imbalances, particularly if you are taking furosemide, which can lead to dehydration or low potassium levels. 

It would be advisable to further evaluate your electrolyte levels and consider physical therapy or other interventions to address the somatic dysfunction and alleviate your symptoms.

question:
I am a 70-year-old woman and have been experiencing worsening leg swelling for the past two months. Alongside this, I have noticed mild intermittent abdominal discomfort and increased fatigue. During this time, I also lost about 3.2 kg unintentionally and have had occasional visible blood in my urine.

I have not experienced any chest pain or shortness of breath. When my vital signs were checked, they were normal, and my heart and lungs were assessed without any issues. There was no noticeable elevation in jugular venous pressure, and my abdomen was non-distended with no palpable masses. However, there was mild tenderness on the right side of my abdomen, but there was no rebound tenderness or guarding.

Upon examining my legs, the doctor noted 2+ edema that extended to my hips, although my peripheral pulses were intact. Urine tests indicated no proteinuria but showed a slight presence of blood. Further analysis of my urine revealed 10 to 15 red blood cells per high-power field. 

Based on these observations and findings, I am awaiting a diagnosis that could explain my symptoms and the results of my examinations.
options: A. Renal vein thrombosis B. Congestive heart failure C. Acute glomerulonephritis D. Renal-cell carcinoma E. Membranous nephropathy F. Nephrotic syndrome G. Immunoglobulin A nephropathy H. IgA nephropathy I. Polycystic kidney disease J. Renal-vein thrombosis
default:
Your symptoms and findings suggest a potential underlying issue that could be related to kidney function or vascular health. The combination of worsening leg swelling, abdominal discomfort, unintentional weight loss, fatigue, and the presence of blood in your urine raises concerns for conditions such as kidney disease, possible urinary tract issues, or even a vascular problem like deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or heart failure, despite normal vital signs.

The mild tenderness in the right abdomen and the presence of red blood cells in your urine could indicate a renal issue, such as a kidney stone or glomerulonephritis. The significant leg edema could also suggest fluid retention due to kidney dysfunction or heart-related issues, even in the absence of overt symptoms like chest pain.

question:
I am a 17-year-old female, and recently my mother expressed concern about my decreased appetite and weight loss of about 4 kg over the past four months. I have noticed that I've lost interest in eating, which has been affecting my overall well-being. Additionally, my academic performance has declined over the past year, and I've been experiencing frequent conflicts with my parents regarding my future plans.

My mother has also observed that I've been more nervous and restless lately. There is a family history of thyroid disease, as my grandmother had it. I am currently sexually active with two male partners but have been inconsistent with using condoms.

During a physical examination, my height was noted to be at the 60th percentile, my weight at the 30th percentile, and my BMI at the 20th percentile. My vital signs showed a temperature of 37°C, a pulse of 104 beats per minute, and my blood pressure was measured at 135/80 mm Hg. The examination revealed 9 mm pupils with minimal light reactivity, normal deep tendon reflexes, and fine hand tremors, while the rest of the examination appeared unremarkable. Given these observations, I am seeking guidance on what the most appropriate initial diagnostic step should be.
options: A. Perform psychiatric evaluation for eating disorders B. Measure TSH, fT3, fT4 C. Order complete blood count and metabolic panel D. Measure cortisol levels E. Measure serum electrolytes F. Obtain toxicology screening G. Order abdominal ultrasound H. Obtain brain MRI I. Perform ECG and cardiac workup J. Screen for autoimmune disorders
default: Given your symptoms of decreased appetite, weight loss, increased nervousness, and the family history of thyroid disease, the most appropriate initial diagnostic step would be to perform a thyroid function test. This typically includes measuring levels of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) to assess for potential thyroid dysfunction, such as hyperthyroidism.

question:
I am a 22-year-old marathon trainee who recently developed lumbosacral back pain that has persisted for a week. This pain has been significant enough to halt my training. I have noticed tightness in my right lower back and buttock, which worsens when I transition from sitting to standing. The discomfort has impacted my daily activities and my ability to train effectively. 

During this period, I have been mindful of how my symptoms present themselves, especially during movements that involve my lower back. I am aware that certain physical examinations could reveal more about my condition, particularly in relation to potential nerve involvement or muscular tightness. I have been considering the possible outcomes of any examination that a healthcare provider might conduct, including tests that evaluate for conditions such as sciatic nerve compression or issues related to the hip and sacroiliac joints. 

Overall, my focus has been on understanding the nature of my back pain and the implications it may have on my training and overall mobility. This experience has prompted me to seek further evaluation to determine the best course of action for recovery and resuming my marathon training.
options: A. Positive straight leg raise test with radicular symptoms B. Positive FAIR test with sciatic nerve compression symptoms C. Positive piriformis stretch test with contralateral hip rotation D. Positive Thomas test and positive pelvic shift test to the ipsilateral side as the dysfunction E. Positive Patrick's test with ipsilateral sacroiliac joint tenderness F. Negative Thomas test and negative pelvic shift test G. Positive Thomas test and positive pelvic shift test to the contralateral side of the dysfunction H. Positive Ober test with limited hip adduction I. Tender point lateral to ASIS J. Positive FABER test with decreased range of motion bilaterally
solution_text: Positive Thomas test and positive pelvic shift test to the contralateral side of the dysfunction
default:
It sounds like you're experiencing significant lumbosacral back pain, potentially related to muscle tightness or nerve involvement. Given your symptoms, it's important to consult a healthcare provider for a thorough evaluation. They may perform physical examinations to assess for nerve compression, such as the straight leg raise test, and evaluate your hip and sacroiliac joint function. 

In the meantime, consider rest, gentle stretching, and applying heat or ice to the affected area. Avoid activities that exacerbate your pain. Once evaluated, a tailored rehabilitation program can help you recover and safely resume your marathon training.
alternative: Positive Thomas test and positive pelvic shift test to the contralateral side of the dysfunction

question:
I was brought to the emergency department after being found minimally responsive at a homeless shelter. I have a history of intravenous drug use, which likely contributed to my condition. At the time of arrival, I was unable to provide any history due to my level of consciousness. My temperature was measured at 96.6°F, blood pressure was low at 84/44 mmHg, my pulse was elevated at 150 beats per minute, and my respirations were at 17 per minute. My oxygen saturation was at 98% on room air.

Despite receiving 3 liters of fluids, my vital signs did not improve. A physical examination revealed multiple abscesses in my antecubital fossae and a cardiac murmur. My Glasgow Coma Scale score was assessed at 6, which led to the decision to intubate me after I was given an induction agent and a paralytic medication.

Following intubation, my blood pressure dropped further within the next 15 minutes. However, it improved quickly after I was administered stress dose steroids. The medical team was concerned about the cause of my post-intubation hypotension, but I was unable to engage in discussions regarding my treatment at that time.
options: A. Fentanyl B. Cisatracurium C. Propofol D. Atracurium E. Etomidate F. Ketamine G. Rocuronium H. Vecuronium I. Midazolam J. Succinylcholine
default: Your presentation suggests a case of septic shock, likely due to an infection related to your intravenous drug use, evidenced by the abscesses and cardiac murmur. The initial hypotension and subsequent worsening after intubation could indicate adrenal insufficiency, particularly given the rapid improvement with stress dose steroids. This scenario is consistent with the possibility of acute adrenal crisis, especially in the context of significant stress from illness and intubation. The combination of low blood pressure, elevated heart rate, and altered mental status further supports this diagnosis. Immediate management with fluids, antibiotics, and steroids was appropriate in this critical situation.

question:
I am a 30-year-old woman who has been experiencing several health issues over the past three months, including constipation, fatigue, muscle weakness, increased urination, and excessive thirst. I have a medical history that includes hypertension, which I manage with a daily dose of amlodipine at 5 mg. Additionally, I have been receiving treatment for bipolar disorder with lithium at a dosage of 300 mg three times daily for the last two years.

During a recent physical examination, my blood pressure was measured at 130/82 mm Hg, my heart rate was 78 beats per minute, and my body mass index (BMI) was recorded at 32. I noted that my serum calcium level had been 9.8 mg/dL three years prior. 

As part of my evaluation, various laboratory tests were conducted, but I am not including the specific results here. I am currently trying to understand the most appropriate next steps for managing my condition, given my symptoms and medical history. I am considering various options that could help address my ongoing health concerns.
options: A. Increase amlodipine dosage B. Order bone mineral density scan C. Order nuclear imaging of the parathyroid glands D. Initiate treatment with cinacalcet E. Begin treatment with bisphosphonates F. Reduce lithium dosage by 50% G. Measure 24-hour urinary calcium excretion H. Replace lithium with an alternative treatment for bipolar disorder I. Perform ultrasound of the parathyroid glands J. Order genetic testing for MEN1 syndrome
solution_text: Replace lithium with an alternative treatment for bipolar disorder
default:
Given your symptoms of constipation, fatigue, muscle weakness, increased urination, and excessive thirst, along with your history of lithium use, it’s important to consider the possibility of lithium-induced hypercalcemia or renal issues, as lithium can affect kidney function and calcium metabolism.

The next steps should include:

1. **Serum Lithium Level**: Ensure your lithium levels are within the therapeutic range, as toxicity can lead to similar symptoms.
2. **Renal Function Tests**: Assess kidney function (creatinine, BUN) to rule out any renal impairment.
3. **Calcium Levels**: Check serum calcium and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels to evaluate for hyperparathyroidism or other causes of hypercalcemia.
alternative: Replace lithium with an alternative treatment for bipolar disorder

question:
I am a 27-year-old male who recently sought help due to ongoing anxiety and moodiness. I have been feeling particularly stressed at home and work. My medical history includes chronic gastritis, which was treated for *Helicobacter pylori*, chronic pyelonephritis with kidney stones, and I am also classified as having stage 1 chronic kidney disease. I have been smoking for eight years and have tried to quit using nicotine patches, but each attempt has led to increased anxiety.

Recently, I lost my grandfather, who was a heavy smoker, to metastatic lung cancer, which has added to my stress. During my visit, my vital signs and physical examination were normal. My healthcare provider mentioned considering a partial nicotine agonist for my smoking cessation efforts. Prior to starting this treatment, I was informed that a specific test needed to be performed, though I was not clear on which one would be appropriate.

I understand that managing my anxiety and mood is crucial, especially considering my medical history and the stress I am experiencing.
options: A. Electrocardiogram B. Mini-Mental State Examination C. Pulmonary function testing D. Complete blood count E. Serum potassium levels F. 9-item patient health questionnaire G. Echocardiography H. Liver function tests I. Creatinine J. Fagerström Test for Nicotine Dependence
default: Given your situation, it sounds like your healthcare provider is likely considering a medication like varenicline (Chantix), which is a partial nicotine agonist used for smoking cessation. Before starting this treatment, a common test that may be required is a renal function test, particularly since you have stage 1 chronic kidney disease. This is important to ensure that the medication is safe for you, as it can affect kidney function. Additionally, monitoring your mental health and anxiety levels will be crucial as you navigate this process. It's essential to discuss any concerns with your healthcare provider to ensure a comprehensive approach to your treatment.

question:
I am a 29-year-old woman who recently attended my annual health maintenance examination. Overall, I feel well and have no history of serious illnesses. I do not take any medications. My menarche began at age 10, and I have regular menstrual cycles every 28 days, lasting about 5 days with moderate flow. I am sexually active in a monogamous relationship with my husband and use a copper intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception.

During the visit, my height was measured at 167 cm and my weight at 92 kg, resulting in a BMI of 33. My vital signs were within normal limits. The physician conducted a physical examination, including a pelvic exam, and found no abnormalities. However, a transvaginal ultrasound revealed a well-positioned IUD and identified a 3.5-cm, concentric, hypoechoic, heterogeneous mass in the posterior myometrial wall. This finding was new, as a previous ultrasound performed four years ago when the IUD was placed showed no abnormalities.

The physician discussed potential next steps in management, considering the nature of the mass and my overall health status. Various options were presented, but a decision is yet to be made regarding the most appropriate course of action.
options: A. Begin oral contraceptive therapy B. Remove IUD and monitor symptoms C. Remove copper IUD and prescribe oral contraceptive therapy D. Initiate GnRH agonist therapy E. Refer for gynecologic oncology consultation F. Recommend uterine artery embolization G. Order serum CA-125 testing H. Repeat ultrasonography in 6 months I. Perform hysteroscopy with endometrial biopsy J. Schedule immediate myomectomy
default:
Given the findings of a 3.5-cm, concentric, hypoechoic, heterogeneous mass in the posterior myometrial wall, the most appropriate next step in management would typically involve further evaluation to determine the nature of the mass. This may include:

1. **MRI of the pelvis**: This imaging can provide more detailed information about the mass, helping to differentiate between benign and malignant processes.

2. **Follow-up ultrasound**: Depending on the characteristics of the mass, a follow-up ultrasound may be warranted to monitor any changes over time.

3. **Biopsy**: If there is concern for malignancy or if the mass is symptomatic, a biopsy may be necessary to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

4. **Consultation

question:
I arrived at the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. I was experiencing pain on the left side of my chest, which intensified with deep breaths, and I had significant shortness of breath. Upon examination, my temperature was recorded at 37.0°C (98.6°F), my pulse was 130 beats per minute, and my respirations were 24 breaths per minute. My blood pressure was measured at 100/75 mmHg, and my oxygen saturation level was 85% on room air.

The medical staff assessed me and noted that there were no penetrating injuries, but I had visible bruising over my left chest wall. They observed that my trachea was deviated to the right, and my chest expansion on the left side was reduced. I could sense the urgency in the room as the healthcare team considered the next steps in my management.
options: A. Administer intravenous fluids B. Place a chest tube C. Administer analgesics and observe D. Obtain an arterial blood gas E. Perform emergency thoracotomy F. Obtain a chest x-ray G. Perform pericardiocentesis H. Perform endotracheal intubation I. Perform needle thoracostomy J. Provide supplemental oxygen
default:
Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it is likely that you are experiencing a tension pneumothorax. The key indicators include:

- Chest pain on the left side, worsening with deep breaths.
- Significant shortness of breath.
- Tracheal deviation to the right.
- Reduced chest expansion on the left side.
- Hypoxia (oxygen saturation of 85%).
- Bruising over the left chest wall.

Immediate management would involve needle decompression of the affected side to relieve the pressure, followed by chest tube placement for ongoing management. Prompt intervention is critical to prevent respiratory failure and other complications.

question:
I am a 38-year-old woman, and I have been experiencing progressively worsening weakness and numbness for the past three months. Initially, the symptoms began in my lower legs, but they have gradually spread to my upper legs and arms. Over the last five days, I have also had headaches and have found it increasingly difficult to smile, talk, and drink.

I have a history of chronic hepatitis B infection and Graves disease. I am sexually active with one male partner, although I use condoms inconsistently. My current medications include methimazole and a multivitamin.

During my examination, my vital signs were normal, and I was alert and oriented. However, I was found to have bilateral upper and lower facial paralysis, generalized muscle weakness in my extremities, decreased sensation to light touch throughout my body, and absent sensation in my fingertips and toes. The deep tendon reflexes were diminished bilaterally.

Given these symptoms and findings, further evaluation is required to understand the underlying cause of my condition. I am awaiting additional tests to determine the most likely diagnosis.
options: A. Reduced serum vitamin B12 levels B. Positive GM1 ganglioside autoantibodies C. Elevated anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies D. Positive ANA with speckled pattern E. Positive Campylobacter stool culture F. Elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count G. Positive anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies H. Positive anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies I. Positive Lyme disease serology J. Decreased nerve conduction velocities on electromyography
default: Your symptoms and examination findings suggest a possible neurological condition, such as Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) or a myasthenic syndrome. The progressive weakness, facial paralysis, and sensory changes, along with diminished reflexes, are concerning for an autoimmune process affecting the peripheral nervous system. Given your history of chronic hepatitis B and Graves disease, it's important to consider potential autoimmune or infectious etiologies. Further evaluation, including lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis and nerve conduction studies, will be crucial in determining the diagnosis. Immediate medical attention is warranted due to the risk of respiratory involvement and other complications.

question:
I attended my routine wellness visit at the doctor's office recently. My mother mentioned that I have had no health issues since my last appointment, but she expressed concerns about my academic performance. At school, I have been facing significant challenges and receive weekly disciplinary actions due to my disruptive behavior. My teacher has noted that I struggle to understand instructions and my reading skills are below what is expected for my grade.

I have also experienced communication difficulties, which have led to incidents like urinating in class when I couldn't express my need to use the bathroom. During playtime, I interact with my peers, but sometimes my behavior is not appropriate for my age.

During my physical examination, I appeared healthy, and my vital signs were normal. I made good eye contact and smiled with the doctor, but the doctor did observe me flapping my arms occasionally when they were discussing things with my mom. My hearing was tested and found to be normal, and there were no issues with my mouth or tongue.

Overall, I am trying to cope with these challenges, and my mother is looking for answers regarding what might be affecting me.
options: A. Sensory processing disorder B. Fragile X syndrome C. Specific learning disability D. Global developmental delay E. Childhood apraxia of speech F. Autism spectrum disorder G. Rett syndrome H. Social (pragmatic) communication disorder I. Intellectual disability J. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
default: Based on the information provided, it seems you may be experiencing challenges that could be related to a developmental or learning disorder, such as Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) or a specific learning disability. The communication difficulties, disruptive behavior, struggles with understanding instructions, and social interactions suggest that further evaluation by a specialist, such as a psychologist or a developmental pediatrician, may be beneficial. They can provide a comprehensive assessment to identify any underlying issues and recommend appropriate interventions or support strategies to help you succeed academically and socially. It's important for your mother to discuss these concerns with your healthcare provider to explore the next steps.

question:
I am a 32-year-old female who went to the emergency department due to sudden vision loss in my left eye that started this evening. I had never experienced anything like this before and do not have a regular medical care routine or take any medications. 

In my medical history, I recall having occasional episodes of weakness and numbness that resolved on their own. When I arrived at the hospital, my vital signs were taken: my temperature was 97.6°F, blood pressure was 120/74 mmHg, my pulse was 88 beats per minute, my respirations were 12 per minute, and my oxygen saturation was 98% on room air.

During the physical examination, the doctor noted decreased sensation over the top of my left foot. Additionally, the examination of my eyes confirmed that I had lost vision in my left eye, which was accompanied by pain. 

I was informed that further clinical findings could help clarify my condition, and several options were presented for consideration. Overall, the experience was concerning, and I sought medical evaluation to understand the cause of my symptoms.
options: A. Positive Romberg sign B. Ptosis and diplopia worsening throughout the day C. Ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration sensation D. Segmental demyelination on nerve conduction studies E. Bilateral spastic paresis of the lower extremities F. Weakness with repeat exertion G. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation H. Electrical pain with neck flexion I. Decreased deep tendon reflexes in the affected limb J. Hyperreflexia in the lower extremities
default: Your symptoms of sudden vision loss in the left eye, accompanied by pain and a history of transient episodes of weakness and numbness, raise concern for a possible neurological condition. Given your age and the acute nature of your symptoms, one potential diagnosis could be optic neuritis, which is often associated with multiple sclerosis. The decreased sensation in your left foot may also suggest a neurological issue. It is crucial to undergo further evaluation, including imaging studies like an MRI and possibly a lumbar puncture, to assess for demyelinating diseases or other underlying conditions. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to address your symptoms and prevent further complications.

question:
I am a 50-year-old male who recently went to the emergency department due to acute abdominal pain. Over the past several months, I had been experiencing discomfort after meals, which I managed with over-the-counter antacids. However, the pain worsened significantly about an hour before my visit. This severe epigastric pain radiated to my right shoulder and was accompanied by nausea and vomiting. I did not have any fever, chills, or cough.

My medical history includes hypertension, which I manage with amlodipine, and I have never had any surgeries. I work as a carpenter and do not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit drugs. 

Upon examination in the emergency department, my temperature was recorded at 101.0°F. My blood pressure was 110/60 mmHg, my pulse was 110 beats per minute, and my respirations were 22 per minute. The physical examination revealed diffuse abdominal rigidity, rebound tenderness, and hypoactive bowel sounds. 

Given these symptoms and findings, the medical team discussed the most appropriate next diagnostic step to further investigate my condition.
options: A. Blood cultures and broad-spectrum antibiotics B. Serum lipase and amylase testing C. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) D. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage E. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan F. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen G. Exploratory laparotomy H. Admission and serial abdominal exams I. Abdominal ultrasound J. Chest radiograph
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, the most appropriate next diagnostic step would be to perform an abdominal ultrasound. This imaging study can help assess for gallbladder disease, such as cholecystitis, which is consistent with your severe epigastric pain, radiation to the shoulder, and signs of abdominal rigidity and tenderness.

question:
I am a 44-year-old individual living with HIV. Recently, I was brought to the emergency department due to increasing confusion that had been noticed by the staff at the homeless shelter where I reside. Upon my arrival, I reported experiencing a headache and muscle pain, but I struggled to provide more detailed information about my condition.

While in the emergency department, the medical team took my vital signs. My temperature was recorded at 102.2°F, my blood pressure was 112/71 mmHg, my heart rate was 115 beats per minute, and my respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute. During the physical examination, the doctor noted resistance and pain when I attempted to extend my knees while my hips were flexed.

To further investigate my symptoms, the medical team performed a lumbar puncture. They observed that the opening pressure was normal, the fluid was clear, but there was an elevated cell count with lymphocytes, and the protein level was mildly elevated. Based on these findings, the medical professionals began considering potential causes for my clinical presentation.
options: A. Listeria monocytogenes B. Varicella-zoster virus C. Epstein-Barr virus D. Herpes simplex virus E. Cytomegalovirus F. Neisseria meningitidis G. Cryptococcus H. West Nile virus I. Mycobacterium tuberculosis J. Toxoplasma gondii
default: Based on the clinical presentation and lumbar puncture findings, the most likely diagnosis is viral meningitis, possibly due to HIV-related complications or another viral infection. The elevated lymphocyte count and mildly elevated protein level in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), along with the patient's immunocompromised status, support this diagnosis. The confusion, headache, and muscle pain further align with viral meningitis symptoms. It's important for the medical team to consider additional testing for specific viral pathogens, including HIV itself, to guide treatment.

question:
I am a 25-year-old woman seeking evaluation for primary amenorrhea. I do not have a significant medical history and currently do not take any medications. I am not sexually active.

During my physical examination, my height was measured at 132 cm, and I weighed 49 kg. My blood pressure was recorded at 125/85 mm Hg, and my heart rate was noted to be 80 beats per minute. The examination revealed a webbed neck, but there was no enlargement of the thyroid. I also have a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Breast development and pubic hair were assessed, and both were found to be consistent with Tanner stage 2, indicating some sexual maturity. 

Additionally, the cardiac examination included auscultation, where an early systolic ejection click was detected. This finding raised the question of potential cardiac anomalies that might be present, prompting further investigation with an echocardiogram.
options: A. Bicuspid aortic valve B. Ventricular septal defect C. Tricuspid valve regurgitation D. Atrial septal defect E. Pulmonary valve stenosis F. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome G. Mitral valve prolapse H. Pulmonary stenosis I. Coarctation of the aorta J. Aortic root dilation
default: Based on the provided information, the clinical presentation is suggestive of Turner syndrome, particularly given the webbed neck, short stature, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and primary amenorrhea. The early systolic ejection click may indicate a potential cardiac anomaly, which is common in Turner syndrome, such as aortic coarctation or other structural heart defects. An echocardiogram is warranted to assess for these potential cardiac issues. Further evaluation, including karyotyping, would help confirm the diagnosis of Turner syndrome.

question:
I am a 72-year-old woman who recently went to the emergency department due to a two-week history of worsening shortness of breath. Alongside this, I noticed swelling in my lower extremities and an unexpected weight gain of about 3 kilograms (6.6 pounds). 

During my examination, the doctor listened to my chest and noted the presence of crackles. They also conducted a cardiac examination and detected a dull, low-pitched sound during early diastole at the fifth left intercostal space. This sound became more pronounced when I was positioned on my left side and during the end of my breath out. 

The medical team evaluated my symptoms and findings to determine the underlying cause of these auscultatory results.
options: A. Increased left ventricular end-systolic volume B. Left atrial enlargement C. Impaired mitral valve closure D. Decreased cardiac output E. Increased left atrial pressure F. Decreased left-ventricular filling pressure G. Decreased left myocardial compliance H. Increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure I. Decreased stroke volume J. Impaired diastolic relaxation
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it is likely that you are experiencing heart failure, possibly due to fluid overload. The worsening shortness of breath, lower extremity swelling, and weight gain suggest fluid retention. The presence of crackles in your lungs indicates pulmonary congestion, and the low-pitched sound you described, likely a third heart sound (S3), is often associated with heart failure. The fact that this sound becomes more pronounced in certain positions further supports this diagnosis. It would be important for your medical team to conduct further tests, such as an echocardiogram, to assess your heart function and determine the best course of treatment.

question:
I am an 18-year-old female cross-country runner, and I recently visited the clinic due to a 2-week history of pain in both of my feet. The pain began the morning after a competition and has been consistently present since then. I noticed that the pain improves when I rest but worsens with activity as the day goes on. Despite trying rest and applying ice, my symptoms have not improved.

During my visit, the healthcare provider checked my vital signs, which were normal, and noted that my BMI is 22 kg/m². On physical examination, the provider found diffuse tenderness on the plantar surfaces of my proximal metatarsals bilaterally, but there was no specific point tenderness. The examination revealed no signs of pes planus, calcaneal pain, or tenderness in the Achilles tendon. Additionally, the fibular head motion was unremarkable, and bilateral foot radiographs did not show any abnormalities.

Given these findings, I am left wondering about the most likely cause of my foot pain. The options provided include conditions such as sesamoiditis, Morton's neuroma, and plantar fasciitis, among others. I hope to get clarity on my diagnosis and the next steps for treatment.
options: A. Sesamoiditis B. Morton's neuroma C. Lateral longitudinal arch somatic dysfunction D. Plantar fasciitis E. Metatarsal stress fractures F. Tarsal tunnel syndrome G. Peroneal tendinopathy H. Flexor hallucis longus tendinitis I. Medial tibial stress syndrome J. Transverse arch somatic dysfunction
default:
Based on your symptoms and examination findings, the most likely cause of your foot pain is **metatarsalgia** or **stress reaction** in the metatarsal region, particularly given the diffuse tenderness on the plantar surfaces of your proximal metatarsals and the history of increased activity following a competition. 

The pain improving with rest and worsening with activity aligns with overuse injuries common in runners. Since there is no specific point tenderness or signs of other conditions like plantar fasciitis or Morton's neuroma, metatarsalgia is a strong possibility.

For treatment, consider the following steps:
1. **Rest**: Continue to limit activities that exacerbate the pain.
2. **Ice**: Apply ice to the affected areas to

question:
I am an 11-year-old male who recently attended a well-child examination for pre-school and sports clearance. During the visit, my mother mentioned that a previous pediatrician had observed a spinal curve in me, but there were no other medical issues or surgical history to report. 

At the examination, I was measured and found to be at the 60th percentile for height and the 65th percentile for weight relative to my age group. The doctor performed a physical examination and noted three significant findings: I had enhanced thoracic kyphosis, my right scapula was positioned posteriorly while standing in a neutral stance, and there was a group dysfunction from T3 to T9 upon spinal palpation. 

When I was asked to bend forward, the doctor observed a prominent hump on the right side of my rib cage. Based on these findings, the doctor discussed the nature of my spinal motion pattern and potential diagnoses, highlighting the characteristics observed during the examination.
options: A. Dextroscoliosis; freedom of motion is sidebent to the right and rotated to the left B. Dextroscoliosis; concavity of the curve is to the left and vertebrae rotated to the right C. Levoscoliosis; concavity of the curve is to the right and vertebrae rotated to the left D. Levoscoliosis; the curve is sidebent to the right and rotated to the left E. Levoscoliosis; freedom of motion is sidebent to the right and rotated to the left F. Levoscoliosis; restricted with extension and convexity of the curve is to the left G. Dextroscoliosis; restricted with flexion and concavity of the curve is to the left H. Levoscoliosis; freedom of motion is sidebent to the left and rotated to the right I. Dextroscoliosis; convexity of the curve is to the left and vertebrae rotated to the left J. Dextroscoliosis; convexity of the curve is to the right and vertebrae rotated to the left
solution_text: Dextroscoliosis; concavity of the curve is to the left and vertebrae rotated to the right
default: Based on the findings from your examination, it appears that you may have a condition known as scoliosis, specifically a right thoracic curve. The enhanced thoracic kyphosis, the posterior positioning of the right scapula, and the prominent rib hump observed when bending forward are all indicative of this condition. Scoliosis can lead to asymmetry in the spine and rib cage, which aligns with the observations made during your physical examination. It would be advisable to follow up with a specialist, such as an orthopedic doctor, for further evaluation and potential management options.
alternative: Dextroscoliosis; concavity of the curve is to the left and vertebrae rotated to the right

question:
I am a 62-year-old man who recently sought medical attention due to issues with urinary dribbling and increased frequency of urination. My medical history includes hypertension and dyslipidemia, which I manage with medication. During my physical examination, the doctor performed a digital rectal examination and noted a firm 1-centimeter nodule on my prostate gland.

As part of the evaluation, my prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level was measured, and I learned that it was 6.0, which is above the reference range upper limit of 4.0. I was informed that the PSA test has a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 90%. 

Additionally, I was made aware of a recent large cross-sectional study involving 1,000 participants that indicated a 10% prevalence of prostate cancer in men of my age group. Given these factors, I am now considering what my chances might be of having prostate carcinoma based on my symptoms and examination findings.
default:
Given your age, symptoms, the firm nodule on your prostate, and an elevated PSA level of 6.0, your risk of having prostate cancer is significantly increased. 

With a 10% prevalence of prostate cancer in men your age, the elevated PSA level (above 4.0) raises your likelihood further. The sensitivity of the PSA test (80%) means that there is an 80% chance that a man with prostate cancer will have an elevated PSA, while the specificity (90%) indicates a 10% chance of a false positive result.

To estimate your chances of having prostate cancer, you can use the following reasoning:

1. **Base Rate**: Start with the 10% prevalence in your age group.

question:
I am a 41-year-old woman with a medical history that includes three uncomplicated cesarean births and tubal sterilization during my last delivery. Recently, I have been experiencing heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia. My menstrual cycles are regular, occurring every 25 to 26 days and lasting about eight days, without any intermenstrual bleeding. During the first three days of my cycle, I soak through one pad per hour, and I rate the cramping on my heaviest days as a 9 out of 10.

When I visited the healthcare provider, my vital signs were normal, and my body mass index was measured at 22 kg/m². A pelvic examination revealed a 10-week-sized boggy uterus that was mildly tender to touch, but no discrete masses were found, and my adnexa were nontender. A urine pregnancy test returned negative, and bloodwork indicated mild anemia. Following this, a pelvic ultrasound was ordered to further investigate my symptoms. 

I understand that the ultrasound findings will be crucial in determining the most likely diagnosis related to my condition.
options: A. Multiple hyperechoic foci with posterior shadowing in the myometrium B. A focal hypoechoic lesion with irregular borders in the endometrium C. Endometrial polypoid structures with central vascularity D. Thickened endometrial stripe with irregular vascularity E. Symmetrical, homogeneous endometrial thickening F. Asymmetrical, irregular endometrial thickening G. A large, circular hypoechoic structure within the myometrium with posterior shadowing H. Diffuse myometrial calcifications with acoustic shadowing I. Symmetrical, homogeneous myometrial thickening J. Circular anechoic structures within the myometrium without posterior shadowing
solution_text: Circular anechoic structures within the myometrium without posterior shadowing
default: Based on your symptoms—heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, deep dyspareunia, and the pelvic examination findings of a boggy, mildly tender uterus—along with your history of three cesarean deliveries and tubal sterilization, the most likely diagnosis is adenomyosis. The ultrasound will help confirm this by potentially showing an enlarged, irregularly shaped uterus and other characteristic features. Adenomyosis is common in women with a history of uterine surgery and can explain the heavy bleeding and pain you are experiencing.
alternative: Circular anechoic structures within the myometrium without posterior shadowing

question:
I am a 40-year-old female who sought medical attention due to persistent pain in my right forearm. The pain began two days after I fell, landing on my extended right hand. I have been taking ibuprofen, which has provided some partial relief. I maintain an active lifestyle and engage in regular exercise, and my medical history is unremarkable.

During the clinical examination, the doctor noted that my elbow's carrying angle appeared normal, but I had limited supination in my right arm. I underwent X-rays for my right hand and elbow, which showed no abnormalities. 

Given these findings, I was informed that several possible diagnoses were considered, but no definitive conclusion was reached at that time. I appreciate the thoroughness of the examination and the attention given to my symptoms.
options: A. Medial epicondylitis B. Radioulnar synostosis C. Posterior radial head dysfunction D. Olecranon bursitis E. Anterior radial head dysfunction F. Cubital tunnel syndrome G. Annular ligament sprain H. Interosseous membrane dysfunction I. Lateral epicondylitis J. Radial tunnel syndrome
default: Based on your description, it sounds like you may be experiencing a soft tissue injury, such as a sprain or strain, particularly affecting the muscles or tendons around the forearm and elbow. The limited supination suggests possible involvement of the forearm muscles or the radial nerve. Since the X-rays showed no fractures or bony abnormalities, it's likely that the pain is due to a soft tissue injury rather than a structural issue. Continuing to rest the arm, applying ice, and possibly engaging in physical therapy could be beneficial for recovery. If symptoms persist, further evaluation, such as an MRI, may be warranted to assess for any underlying soft tissue damage.

question:
I am a 50-year-old man who visited my primary care provider because I had been experiencing urinary incontinence for the past five months. My symptoms included frequent and urgent urges to urinate both during the day and at night. Often, I would have small-volume leakage before I could reach the bathroom, which was quite distressing. 

I do not have any significant medical history and I am not currently taking any medications. After discussing my symptoms with my doctor, I began a treatment with oxybutynin, which has notably improved my condition. 

Throughout this experience, I have been trying to understand what might be causing these symptoms. My healthcare provider mentioned several potential conditions that could typically present with my clinical picture. While I am still in the process of learning about my situation, I am hopeful that the treatment will continue to help me manage my symptoms effectively.
options: A. Neurogenic bladder B. Prostatic hyperplasia C. Detrusor overactivity D. Urethral stricture E. Acute cystitis F. Diabetes mellitus G. Prostatitis H. Overactive bladder syndrome I. Interstitial cystitis J. Bladder outlet obstruction
default: Your symptoms of urinary incontinence, characterized by urgency and small-volume leakage, suggest a condition known as overactive bladder (OAB). This can occur due to various factors, including age-related changes in bladder function, neurological conditions, or even lifestyle factors. Oxybutynin, an anticholinergic medication, helps relax the bladder muscle and reduce urgency, which explains the improvement you've experienced. It's important to continue discussing your symptoms and treatment options with your healthcare provider to ensure effective management and address any underlying causes.

question:
I am a 27-year-old female college student, and I recently visited my primary care physician due to lifelong bone and muscle aches that have become more intense. Despite maintaining an active lifestyle and a balanced diet, I have been experiencing increased stress from final exams, which I believe may be contributing to my symptoms. I also mentioned to my doctor that I have had occasional episodes of diarrhea.

Currently, I am being treated with acyclovir for HSV, but I have noticed minimal improvement. During the physical examination, my doctor assessed my strength and noted that I had 4/5 strength in all my extremities, along with non-specific diffuse tenderness in my limbs.

I have one sexual partner and generally lead a healthy lifestyle, but the combination of stress and physical symptoms has been concerning. My physician is exploring potential conditions that might be associated with my clinical presentation, considering factors like malabsorption or vitamin deficiencies due to limited sun exposure, among other possibilities. I am awaiting further evaluation to better understand the underlying causes of my symptoms.
options: A. Hyperphosphatemia from excessive dietary intake of phosphate B. Vitamin D deficiency due to limited sun exposure C. Malabsorption due to celiac disease D. A genetic mutation affecting calcium-sensing receptors E. Hypoalbuminemia leading to pseudohypocalcemia F. Anaphylaxis when receiving a transfusion G. Sleep deprivation H. Chronic kidney disease with secondary hyperparathyroidism I. Rash over the metacarpophalangeal joints J. A history of anxiety/depression
default:
Given your symptoms of bone and muscle aches, episodes of diarrhea, and the stress from exams, it's important to consider several potential underlying conditions. The combination of muscle weakness, diffuse tenderness, and gastrointestinal symptoms could suggest issues such as vitamin D deficiency, which is common in individuals with limited sun exposure, or other nutritional deficiencies. Additionally, conditions like fibromyalgia or autoimmune disorders could also be contributing factors.

It's crucial to follow up with your physician for further evaluation, which may include blood tests to check for vitamin levels, inflammatory markers, and possibly tests for malabsorption syndromes. Managing stress through relaxation techniques and ensuring a balanced diet may also help alleviate some symptoms in the meantime.

question:
I am an 8-year-old boy who have been experiencing a wet cough for the past six weeks. This cough tends to worsen in the mornings, and despite trying various treatments like albuterol, prednisone, and cetirizine, my condition hasn’t improved.

I have not had any recent choking incidents, nor do I have a fever, weight loss, or other upper respiratory symptoms. Additionally, no one else in my household is experiencing any symptoms. My immunizations are up to date.

During a recent check-up, my temperature was recorded at 37.7°C, my heart rate was 110 beats per minute, and my respiratory rate was 26 breaths per minute. My oxygen saturation levels were 98% while breathing room air. Although I appeared well and was not in significant distress, the doctor noted that I had rhonchi in my lungs on auscultation. The rest of the physical examination did not reveal any other issues.

Given my symptoms and the examination findings, the doctor is considering the next steps to establish a diagnosis.
options: A. Perform spirometry with bronchodilator testing B. Prescribe a course of oral amoxicillin-clavulanate C. Initiate a trial of inhaled corticosteroids D. Order a mycoplasma IgM antibody test E. Perform a sweat chloride test F. Obtain a nasopharyngeal culture for viral pathogens G. Refer for allergy testing H. Order bronchoscopy I. Prescribe a trial of proton pump inhibitors J. Obtain chest CT
solution_text: Prescribe a course of oral amoxicillin-clavulanate
default:
Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it sounds like you may be experiencing a form of chronic bronchitis or possibly asthma, especially since your cough worsens in the mornings and you have rhonchi in your lungs. The lack of fever and other systemic symptoms, along with a good oxygen saturation level, suggests that a serious infection is less likely.

The next steps may include further diagnostic tests, such as a chest X-ray to rule out any structural issues or infections, and possibly pulmonary function tests to assess your lung function. Additionally, your doctor might consider allergy testing or a trial of inhaled corticosteroids if asthma is suspected. It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider for a comprehensive evaluation and tailored treatment plan.
alternative: Prescribe a course of oral amoxicillin-clavulanate

question:
I am a 36-year-old woman who has been seeking medical attention due to severe menstrual symptoms that have persisted for the past eight months. My menstrual flow is quite heavy, requiring me to use 6 to 8 pads daily during my periods, which last 5 to 6 days and occur regularly every 28 days. I experience intense pelvic cramping that starts two days before my period begins, and I find minimal relief from naproxen.

These symptoms have significantly impacted my life, leading to job loss from my position as a janitor. My medical history includes a tubal sterilization performed about a year ago, and I have had two uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. I maintain a monogamous sexual relationship with my spouse and take only a daily multivitamin. Additionally, I have a 15-pack-year smoking history.

I stand 165 cm tall and weigh 68 kg, which gives me a BMI of 25 kg/m². Recent assessments, including vital signs, a pelvic exam, and various tests such as a complete blood count and transvaginal ultrasound, have all returned normal results. 

Given my ongoing symptoms and their impact on my daily life, I am now considering the most appropriate next step in management.
options: A. Hysterectomy B. Progesterone-only pills C. Diagnostic hysteroscopy D. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device E. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist therapy F. Uterine artery embolization G. Endometrial ablation H. Combined oral contraceptives I. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) J. Dilation and curettage
default: Given your severe menstrual symptoms, heavy flow, and significant impact on your quality of life, the next appropriate step in management would be to consider hormonal therapy. Options such as combined oral contraceptives or a hormonal IUD can help regulate your menstrual cycle, reduce heavy bleeding, and alleviate cramping. If hormonal treatments are not suitable or effective, further evaluation for conditions like endometriosis or fibroids may be warranted, potentially leading to surgical options if necessary. It's essential to discuss these options with your healthcare provider to tailor the approach to your specific needs.

question:
I am a 67-year-old female who recently visited the emergency department due to an acute onset of severe headache accompanied by weakness and numbness on my left side. These symptoms began about two hours before I arrived at the hospital. 

My medical history includes hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes, for which I take enalapril, amlodipine, insulin, and warfarin. Upon examination, I was alert and oriented, although my vital signs indicated an irregular pulse of 90 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 165/94 mm Hg. 

During the neurological exam, the doctor noted that my eyes were deviated to the left and downward, and my pupils were small and nonreactive. I experienced significant weakness on my left side, rated at 2 out of 5, while my right side was normal at 5 out of 5. In addition, my sensation to pinprick and light touch was diminished on the left side but normal on the right side and my face.

The medical team conducted laboratory tests, which indicated an elevated prothrombin time. Based on my symptoms and examination findings, they discussed the possible anatomical locations for a hemorrhage that could be causing these issues.
options: A. Right corona radiata B. Right basal ganglia C. Right temporal lobe D. Right midbrain E. Right internal capsule F. Right putamen G. Right thalamus H. Right cerebellum I. Right frontal lobe J. Pons
default: Based on your symptoms and examination findings, it is likely that you are experiencing a right-sided intracerebral hemorrhage or possibly a subarachnoid hemorrhage. The acute onset of severe headache, left-sided weakness, and neurological deficits, including eye deviation and nonreactive pupils, suggest a significant event in the right hemisphere of the brain, which controls motor function on the opposite side of the body. The elevated prothrombin time indicates a potential bleeding risk, likely exacerbated by your use of warfarin. Immediate imaging, such as a CT scan, would be crucial to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate management.

question:
I am an 86-year-old woman who visited the emergency department after experiencing vertigo and a sensation of impending fall. These symptoms began about four hours before I arrived at the hospital. Although I felt some improvement, I continued to notice a persistent pull to the right side.

During my evaluation, my vital signs were assessed. My blood pressure was recorded at 116/75 mm Hg, my heart rate was 90 beats per minute, and my oxygen saturation level was 99% while I was breathing room air. A physical examination revealed that I had right-sided limb ataxia. Additionally, I experienced diminished pain and temperature sensation on the right side of my face and the left side of my body. 

To further investigate my condition, I underwent a non-contrast head CT, which showed no signs of hemorrhage. The medical team continued to assess my symptoms and physical findings to determine the best course of action for my treatment.
